Posts.Title: My Biopsy Results Are In

Posts.Content: Got the call today. For those not familiar, I had a previous random biopsy March of last year all twelve perfectly clear...just inflammation. Thought I was in the clear, but I was wrong. MRI in December showed a 5mm pirads 3/4 in the middle of the right peripheral lobe. Fusion biopsy last week on that pirads 3/4 with a random 12 core as well. 12 random samples were completely clean. Nothing there. 2 of the right peripheral where the pirads 3/4 was came back with tissue (dont know the exact tissue type, trying to get the path report) that was highly suspicious to ultimately turn into cancer but hadnt yet. Uro oncologist said the old school method was to re biopsy in 3 months but felt there was no merit to that any longer and felt that was too aggressive. Said that a super vast majority of those redo biopsies where the pre-cancer turned into cancer on a later biopsy ended up a who cares gleason 6. So he felt a remeasurenent if PSA at a year would be sufficient and wed go from there. Im not so sure I want to be that conservative. I have my follow up with my doc on 3/29 and will get his thoughts. I would likely suggest 3 or 6 month PSA testing and maybe a guaranteed biopsy again in a year. Thats until one of you tells me something I dont know that upends my thinking. So what says the hive? Im taking this as the best news possible in a bad situation. Ill likely have cancer sooner than later but it sounds like it might be a good AS case if so. Happy Friday all!
Posts.Signature: 2006: 1.6 PSA age 36 2007: 1.3 PSA age 37 2012: 2.2 PSA age 42 2013: 2.6 PSA age 43 2014: 2.8 PSA age 44 2015: 3.1 PSA age 45 2016: 3.5 PSA age 46 2017: ? N/A 3/18 4.1 PSA at 48 YO. u/s measured 46 ml prostate 3/18free PSA 10% 3/1812 core all negative 9/18 4.5 PSA 9/18 negative pca3 12/18- 4K at 17% 12/18- 3t MRI, 5mm pirads 3-4 and a pirads 1-2 2/19- Fusion biopsy. G6 (3+3) 20% of a single core AS for now 4/19-PSA at 7.21 (up from 4.5 in September 2018! Gulp

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Another Maybe a second opinion on the Gleason scoring just to make sure. Then wait. This is what early detection looks like. What is the process to do that? Is it too late?
Posts.Title: Wade on in and discuss fusion biopsy results with sir stressalot!

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by ASAdvocate It seems that you have already been on AS for the past year. Your steadily rising psa and low free psa are cause for continued close monitoring. If you have HGPIN or ASAP, there is no certainty that they will ever become true cancer, or at least not a significant cancer. Your idea for future testing in the next year makes sense. I would suggest PHI rather than psa/fpsa tests, and also that you track your PHI density, which Johns Hopkins has found to be the most reliable test for future significant PCa. See there it is...more stuff I didnt know! ðŸ˜€ Can you clue me in what HGPIN or ASAP or PHI are? In all my thread crashing , never heard of those.
Posts.Title: Wade on in and discuss fusion biopsy results with sir stressalot!

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Southsider You really aren't "AS" yet, as you just have 2 negative biopsies. You don't have cancer. At least not yet. Try to relax Im chillaxed, hey maybe that Valium given to me on the day of the biopsy finally kicked in! ðŸ˜€ Im taking this as good news with a little Ill worry about that later. I just wanted to make sure there wasnt some angle or other thought process. I just got to kick the can farther down the road is how I see this.

Posts.Content: Hi folks, I had labs drawn Thursday and they were published to my portal today. I was hoping to see my normal, continuing steady growth but my PSA jumped from 4.5 in September of last year to a whopping 7.21 on April 18. It had been several days since sex and no bike riding or external sources of trauma. Im consulting a doctor named Dr. Scott Miller in Atlanta. After more bobbles that would take a book to write, Ive decided my existing urology docs arent the MDs for me. I would never let the uro oncologist operate on me, so its time to switch to someone I would. Dr. Miller is named Atlantas top urologist for prostate cancer and has pioneered new surgical procedures using robotics. Hes been on the local and national news many times. So maybe this will end up being a timely switch. Thanks for any information you guys might be able to give. I delayed this draw for two+ months after the biopsy so that it would be healed up and less angry. My take is that my completely harmless G6 2mm one core sample would not likely be the driver of such a large jump. It would seems that absent some other cause, Ive got something else going on in there. Any thoughts guys?

G6 (3+3) 20% of a single core AS for now 4/19-PSA at 7.21 (up from 4.5 in September 2018! Gulp
Posts.Title: New labs and PSA back

Posts.Content: Djin, The odd thing is that my signature is there. In fact I just edited it to add my new results. I have no idea why its there sometimes and sometimes not. Strange. The only thing that concerns me is that this was my second biopsy with the first 12 core random (March 2018 ) being totally clean. The March 2019 2 core fusion (on the pirads 3/4) was clean but hey then did a random 10 core after the fusion. 8 were clean, 1 precancerous and 1 G6. So I would Love to say this is just more G6 but the probability of that seems less given that Ive had 22 samples taken across the prostate and only 1 came back with a 2mm G6. That seems to make it less likely of wide spread G6. As much as I hate it, this seems like something more significant that was missed. But then again it could be prostatitis starting or ending. The pirads 3/4 was indicative of prostatitis or scarring so maybe I have another case. As far as the new provider, I had the 3t in Dec 2018 and that drove the fusion biopsy I had in March 2019 I certainly hope that is close enough I dont have to do either again. I definitely want another biopsy as soon as possible though. So to summarize we dont know Jack! ðŸ˜€ Thanks guys I hope yall have a great Easter weekend and hopefully some downtime.

AgeInfo.Phrase: less given that Ive had 22 samples taken across the prostate

Posts.Title: New labs and PSA back

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Another Glad to see you back. A few notes in the use of language. Unless you are in a professionally managed and monitored AS program you are not in AS. Managing this on your own is valid and taking time to assess your situation is valid, but it is not AS. Your clarity in this disease will come with clarity in your language. Your thoughts, actions and outcomes will follow a shift to your clear use of language around this disease. Most are not clear that our language drives our knowledge and actions and not our thoughts. Once you are clear in the language of this desease you will be clear in your actions. The use of testosterone, regardless of purpose, can manifest in smaller more agressive cancer that is difficult to find and can present early in younger men. Glad you have stopped it. I have two friends my age who are using it. Once I mentioned my situation and cautioned them about it's use they went silent on it. Most men are irrational when it comes to this disease. Sadly, I believe I am unwanted reminder of their lack of care. It has affected our relationship in they don't ask and don't tell. The burden for me is to quietly watch it unfold. My advice is to continue to monitor and diagnois while you upgrade your healthcare support and lose weight in anticipation. You may now be motivated. Also, be cautious of the rock stars in the industry. Search for those with experience with obese men. Don't count calories, count "added" sugars. Natural sugars bound to their original fiber is okay. It is the added (refined) sugars added to low fat and diet foods to compensate for reduced calories that is the culprit. Most labels now list added sugar. You can eat all the calories of fruit, nuts and vegetables you want. Just don't put "reduced fat" salad dressings or toppings on it. The reduced calories have been replaced with sugar. Consider a fiber supplement to support the reduction in food. One without added sugar. Next add in a low salt diet. Added salt, as a flavor enhancer, is also an indicator of poor quality food which contributes to fat gain. This is more difficult than the sugar. Government standards for salt consumption is twice what it should be. This will almost eliminate all processed carbohydrates, such as bread and processed grain anad snacks products. You will intially loath this diet, but the outcome will make you a believer and may save your life. Keep us posted. Watch "That Sugar Film." It is on Prime, Netflick, and youTube. Hi Another! I always appreciate your advice whether I want to hear it or not! ðŸ˜€ But it is always spot on and I really appreciate the helpful info you provide. When you say Im not on AS and am managing it myself, what do you mean? After my biopsy results showing the G6 the current uro oncologist and I talked and decided AS was the path to go and scheduled the next biopsy for September. So Im not managing it myself we just havent made it to the next biopsy. Unless theres something Im supposed to do to be on official AS, Im on it as far as I know. We stopped the testosterone but started clomid to get my own testosterone back to a livable level. I was basically bottomed out and on unintentional hormone therapy without the supplement or clomid. That was misery. But Im thinking Ill now have to stop the clomid as it looks like I have something more involved going on. As far as diet my gp gave me the sugar buster diet and its along the lines of what youre talking about. No breads, no sugars, no potatos, no corn, no honey plus a bunch of other things. Dropped a few pounds already. I switched doctors after several things which completely eradicated my faith in the uro oncologist. Calling me one week apart with different biopsy results and not remembering (or lying that he didnt remember) that he talked to me was one. The last was the disagreement over biopsy sedation. Valium doesnt work on me so they said office fully awake or the hospital outpatient center. So I scheduled for the outpatient center at the hospital only to receive a call back from the docs MA telling me the doctor had canceled my September biopsy in favor of just rechecking PSA and doing an office consult. I felt that was my way or we just wont do it and thats not okay. Right now Im more than a little concerned about this nearly double jump in six months. It just doesnt seem that reasonable that just a G6 would cause that sharp if a rise. I feel like my chances of surgery just rose exponentially. The first google result of course was a cbs news article that a sharp rise year over year was indicative of an aggressive cancer that greatly increased the chances of death whether you have treatment or not. So Im a bit unnerved by this news. I really wasnt expecting a 7+ result.
Posts.Title: New labs and PSA back

Posts.Content: Thanks Another I just got the signature back on my post no idea why it keeps disappearing. Your comments re diet havent fallen on deaf ears. What I need is a list of what I can eat and maybe some simple recipe ideas for breakfast, lunch and dinner. Im extremely busy so meal planning isnt my wheelhouse. If I can find a set it and forget it diet thats perfect and Ill be happy with what I have to eat. If I have to spend a bunch of time thinking about it and money (eating well is expensive), I wont end up sticking with it.

I have two friends my age who are using it. Once I mentioned my situation and cautioned them about it's use they went silent on it. Most men are irrational when it comes to this disease. Sadly, I believe I am unwanted reminder of their lack of care. It has affected our relationship in they don't ask and don't tell. The burden for me is to quietly watch it unfold. My advice is to continue to monitor and diagnois while you upgrade your healthcare support and lose weight in anticipation. You may now be motivated. Also, be cautious of the rock stars in the industry. Search for those with experience with obese men. Don't count calories, count "added" sugars. Natural sugars bound to their original fiber is okay. It is the added (refined) sugars added to low fat and diet foods to compensate for reduced calories that is the culprit. Most labels now list added sugar. You can eat all the calories of fruit, nuts and vegetables you want. Just don't put "reduced fat" salad dressings or toppings on it. The reduced calories have been replaced with sugar. Consider a fiber supplement to support the reduction in food. One without added sugar. Next add in a low salt diet. Added salt, as a flavor enhancer, is also an indicator of poor quality food which contributes to fat gain. This is more difficult than the sugar. Government standards for salt consumption is twice what it should be. This will almost eliminate all processed carbohydrates, such as bread and processed grain anad snacks products. You will intially loath this diet, but the outcome will make you a believer and may save your life. Keep us posted. Watch "That Sugar Film." It is on Prime, Netflick, and youTube. Hi Another! I always appreciate your advice whether I want to hear it or not! ðŸ˜€ But it is always spot on and I really appreciate the helpful info you provide. When you say Im not on AS and am managing it myself, what do you mean? After my biopsy results showing the G6 the current uro oncologist and I talked and decided AS was the path to go and scheduled the next biopsy for September. So Im not managing it myself we just havent made it to the next biopsy. Unless theres something Im supposed to do to be on official AS, Im on it as far as I know. We stopped the testosterone but started clomid to get my own testosterone back to a livable level. I was basically bottomed out and on unintentional hormone therapy without the supplement or clomid. That was misery. But Im thinking Ill now have to stop the clomid as it looks like I have something more involved going on. As far as diet my gp gave me the sugar buster diet and its along the lines of what youre talking about. No breads, no sugars, no potatos, no corn, no honey plus a bunch of other things. Dropped a few pounds already. I switched doctors after several things which completely eradicated my faith in the uro oncologist. Calling me one week apart with different biopsy results and not remembering (or lying that he didnt remember) that he talked to me was one. The last was the disagreement over biopsy sedation. Valium doesnt work on me so they said office fully awake or the hospital outpatient center. So I scheduled for the outpatient center at the hospital only to receive a call back from the docs MA telling me the doctor had canceled my September biopsy in favor of just rechecking PSA and doing an office consult. I felt that was my way or we just wont do it and thats not okay. Right now Im more than a little concerned about this nearly double jump in six months. It just doesnt seem that reasonable that just a G6 would cause that sharp if a rise. I feel like my chances of surgery just rose exponentially. The first google result of course was a cbs news article that a sharp rise year over year was indicative of an aggressive cancer that greatly increased the chances of death whether you have treatment or not. So Im a bit unnerved by this news. I really wasnt expecting a 7+ result.
Posts.Title: New labs and PSA back

Posts.Content: My doc said to become a vegan five days a week and the two non-vegan days stay away from red meat. My personal take is that most of our pca is from dna and if your are predisposed to pca then youre adding fuel to the fire with a bad diet. I think that those who arent predisposed to pca could eat nothing but red meat and dairy and be fine. The problem is, which are you? Im making changes to my diet to lose weight because belly fat also feeds pca not because I can diet away any cancer thats there. My take...I might be wrong and might be right. But it seems every day researchers are overturning the last study that said X was bad for you. You certainly cant hurt yourself or cause cancer by eating right and exercising unless there are too many pesticides on your vegetables.

Posts.Title: To eat or not to eat some things...

Posts.Content: Let me tell you something brother, Valium failed me as well. The next time these urologists want to do a biopsy, I will be hiring cowboy Waynefrom saving Silverman to dart me with multiple large animal tranquilizers. I do not know why the fusion is so much worse than a standard. If it helps you any, I had a Pirads 3/4 and a two which all turned out to be non-cancerous. I did have some pre-cancerous cells in there somewhere around the 3/4. So the MRI isnt an end-all be-all diagnostic tool. Just remember, no matter what the results, Youll still be OK in the long run most likely. Its easy to lose that perspective when waiting on results. Prayers out for you my brother
Posts.Title: My MRI/Ultrasound Fusion Targeted Biopsy Experience

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Sw1218 thank you so much, icestationzebra. i really need the encouragement. U said it. every other time i urinate, sometimes it's only a few sprinkles of blood. then the next time it's all clear. then later on, it looks like a river of blood flowing out of my wee-wee. it scares me sh**less. i'm at the point to where i don't event WANT to go to the bathroom. not as many samples were taken with the fusion, but the TRUS biopsy did not have me bleeding this bad. Had sex yet? They say it might be tinged with blood. Ive donated less blood at the Red Cross! ðŸ˜€. I nearly passed out the first time I looked down. Definitely get some condoms. I had a cot that hit the other day mid stream. It was the size of a large watermelon seed. Well it immediately shocked me and I was trying to figure out what happened. It wasnt painful but shocked me. I changed positions of the firehouse to figure out what happened. Thats when it let go and smacked against the back of the toilet in a bloody mess. It was literally like a watermelon seed spitting contest. I was trying to keep the biopsy and situation quiet but my loud what the hell probably didnt help with opsec ! Sometimes all we can do is laugh. I will definitely need something different or stronger than Valium next time.

Posts.Content: Oh yeah and public service announcement.... they say your first few sexual encounters may have blood in your semen. Well, Ive actually donated less blood when donating to the Red Cross. It was all blood so be prepared. Also its much thinner and free running than semen so unless you want your bed/bedroom/bathroom/kitchen table (if youre adventurous) looking like a CSI crime scene be prepared with a towel or something. Best of luck to you brother!
Posts.Title: First Biopsy completed, waiting for results

Posts.Content: Best of luck to you my friend, your numbers are better than mine. I am starting with a new urologist in the same practice on Friday. So far PSA 4.1 and 4.4 six months later. Free was 10%. 12 core biopsy was perfect, no cancer. Pca3 score was 8. Now we need to see if I need an MRI. My dumb doctors officeone of the reasons Im switching to the other office (hey doc staff can make or break you)gave me 3 Valium to take. They told me they would tell me when to take them but never did. I finally asked after arriving and sitting there for a minute or two. The Valium didnt take effect until breakfast after everything was said and done! I felt it all! But my breakfast bagel experience was wonderful! ðŸ˜€ Good luck with your results!!!
Posts.Title: First Biopsy completed, waiting for results

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Duck2 While a biopsy is not pleasant (mostly due to anxiety) , I don’t see where the procedure warrants sedation. They shoulf have told you they don’t sedate anyone for the procedure. That is the odd thing, talking to the ultrasound tech He said that most of them are done under sedation. The frustrating thing is that I called and emailed asking about the fact that my urologist said it would be under sedation but they had me booked for the valium experience . I never got anything other than a shoulder shrug or non-return calls. I manage through the 12 core random OK. This fusion biopsy was excruciating. Im not a difficult patient at all, despite what you all may think But I was shuffled from one doctor to another with what looks like a poor hand off
Posts.Title: Would this make you angry?

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Consult1 Not at all. A lot of time the insurance company gets the blame and a bad reputation when it's the doctor's office or doctor that dropped the ball. Good I was t sure if it was the wait for results was getting to me. Im not happy, once I get the results I will see what happens and give it a while before I dam the torpedos. If my results come back good, Ill be much less angry than if they dont. I know that makes no sense but the stress is getting to me right now. Finding this out today sent me over the edge.

Hey I asked for opinions and appreciate yours too. For me the 12 core was doable without sedation but not this one. The fusion was awful. Could have been the technique required or whatever....maybe skill of the doc. But this one had me lifting up off the table at times. During the day 12 core I was like take more if you want, be thorough. Not this time!
Posts.Title: Would this make you angry?

Posts.Content: My primary urologist didnt do my fusion biopsy, the resident uro oncologist did it. My doc told me it would be sedated and that the uro oncologist was coordinating the particulars. My uro stepped out of the planning of this when the uro oncologist stepped in. I inquired multiple times with the doctor and staff about sedation and most inquiries went unanswered and I was ultimately told that my insurance company didnt cover it. So today, being my first day back at work, I began the trek to find the responsible party that denied the anesthesia. Talked with my go to claims person (I work for the insurer) and the doctors office never even called to request the sedation. They didnt even try. The Valium didnt work, at all. 30 mg and nothing, I could have driven home. I went through that barbaric fusion biopsy and all 14 snaps and felt every jab and searing pain with each. I felt the stream of blood running down my cheek and was in misery the entire time at least 10-15 minutes. For some reason, it was ten times worse than the random core biopsy that I had done previously. Right now, Im so pissed that I was lied to that Im ready to go down there personally and let the office manager have it about their lazy staff. Am I being unreasonable?

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Another Patience. Nothing to question until the results except the number of cores taken. You can always ask for more cores. 20 is the max I have heard of. Patience? Patience? Aint nobody got time for that! ðŸ˜€ They are going to target the pirads 3-4, I presume they will hit it in several places since its 5mm and we know the MRI is inaccurate. They might also target the pirads 1-2 just out of an abundance of caution. The doctor doing it didnt have my records in front of him but said if it was big enough theyd sample it too. After they are done they will do a 12 core random. My thought is Im asleep for this one, do everything you can while Im asleep. I do not think that I will be able to be still enough for the biopsy for the precision they needed.
Posts.Title: Diagnosis question

Posts.Content: Hi guys and gals, Maybe this thread will help others but I know it could help me. Im having my fusion biopsy on 2/13 and I want to be prepared for the results and have some well thought out questions ready. I dont know if the results will come over the phone or in person but I know I cannot wait until my next scheduled appointment on 3/29. If just inflammation or prostatitis as suggested by the MRI (please Lord let it be that) then I will have had two random 12 cores plus the fusion biopsy of the pirads 3-4 all of which were clean. My thinking is that there would really be nothing else we can do but monitor PSA and redo the MRI. Am I missing anything I should ask for or some other treatment plan for what would be a continued BPH diagnosis? If its pca obviously I will need the Gleason score. But thats where everything gets confusing and I know that many answers will depend on the Gleason score. Is there any extended information I should ask for? Do I ask for a second opinion on the scoring? I keep seeing people talking about the Cleveland Clinic, do I ask for a referral there? Second opinion on how to proceed? Ill be a little lost if this is the disagnosis. Any tidbits of information from your experience that can help me in the event of either path? Im thinking your stories and tips might help me in whats likely to be great news or bad news. Thanks in advance

Posts.Content: My primary urologist didnt do my fusion biopsy, the resident uro oncologist did it. My doc told me it would be sedated and that the uro oncologist was coordinating the particulars. My uro stepped out of the planning of this when the uro oncologist stepped in. I inquired multiple times with the doctor and staff about sedation and most inquiries went unanswered and I was ultimately told that my insurance company didnt cover it. So today, being my first day back at work, I began the trek to find the responsible party that denied the anesthesia. Talked with my go to claims person (I work for the insurer) and the doctors office never even called to request the sedation. They didnt even try. The Valium didnt work, at all. 30 mg and nothing, I could have driven home. I went through that barbaric fusion biopsy and all 14 snaps and felt every jab and searing pain with each. I felt the stream of blood running down my cheek and was in misery the entire time at least 10-15 minutes. For some reason, it was ten times worse than the random core biopsy that I had done previously. Right now, Im so pissed that I was lied to that Im ready to go down there personally and let the office manager have it about their lazy staff. Am I being unreasonable?

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Consult1 Not at all. A lot of time the insurance company gets the blame and a bad reputation when it's the doctor's office or doctor that dropped the ball. Good I was t sure if it was the wait for results was getting to me. Im not happy, once I get the results I will see what happens and give it a while before I dam the torpedos. If my results come back good, Ill be much less angry than if they dont. I know that makes no sense but the stress is getting to me right now. Finding this out today sent me over the edge.
Posts.Title: Would this make you angry?

Posts.Content: Post biopsy instructions say you might see blood for a few days. Today is the 11th day since my biopsy and I noticed Im still shooting out small clots and brownish blood in the urine, which Im not alarmed about. However the BM seem to be putting out a decent amount of bright red blood this morning. The toilet paper was basically bright red across the width and breadth of it. I got caught in traffic yesterday and really had to have a BM so Im not sure If that extended pressure might have reopened the wounds from the biopsy. No temperature and Im definitely not hemorrhaging or anything like that, just blood coming out as the bowels move. Problem to worry about or meh, suck it up buttercup
Posts.Title: Blood after biopsy

Posts.Content: Welcome to the party pal, were nearly in the same boat. Im 48. My PSA was 4.5 at the last measure after climbing for many years. My PSA hit 4.1 in March of last year, Dre clear. Free was 10%. so we did the 12 core biopsy and all was clear. I was about to be put on a year cycle between appts when I switched doctors within the same practice to a doc closer to home and one that specializes in testosterone replacement since I had to stop it when the scare happened. He did the 4K blood test that came back at 17% and then the MRI that found one pirads 1-2 and a 5mm pirads 3-4. I have a fusion biopsy scheduled for 2/12 and while under they will do another 12 core. So far I dont have cancer and the MRI suggested the 3-4 was prostatitis or scarring from inflammation. But I feel it will likely be cancer. Your stats look better than mine mostly, I think. so you might be okay and this could all be due to scarring or inflammation. Id guess that given your low PSA anything found that would be cancerous would usually be in the early stages. From my limited experience you most definitely need a biopsy and preferably one that is MRI guided so they can get the specific spots they found. I personally would not accept no for an answer as to doing a biopsy sampling them both and then would suggest that they do a 12 core random after completing the fusion. That targets the area found plus does a random. But Im a worrier and am aggressive with my treatment and need to know. The way I understand pca is this. Think of a swimming pool. PCa happens like algae bloom...you might see a spot in the deep end but it could also be in several places just undetected. So the advice is: 1) find a good uro you like and trust them. 2) be ready for the fact that youll not be getting definitive answers at all. Diagnosis and treatment are an art form and there are precious few absolutes. 3) be prepared for the fact that no one generally gets in a hurry because this is slow growing 4) do not be hesitant to be pushy until you come up with a plan that you understand and agree with philosophically 5) realize that even if this is cancer it will likely be okay. My doc told me that even if the 5mm piece is cancer its extremely early and he wouldnt get excited. 6) dont let this consume you, its easy to do. Breathe and relax. Hang in there brother
Posts.Title: New to this whole thing

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Southsider Certainly a lot longer than what I experienced after any of my biopsies. I wouldn't panic over it, but I would give a call to the doctor next Monday if it doesn't stop and definitely mention it. For bleeding to continue for 2 weeks after being poked a few times with a needle is pretty rare. Will do thanks for the reply and suggestion. My last one didnt bleed this long either. However this time I had what felt and looked like a river of blood ooze out during the procedure. And he had the nurse hold pressure on the wound area for 5 minutes or so after he was done and left. Im hoping it was just waiting too long to go yesterday. It was painful.
Posts.Title: Blood after biopsy

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by OldTiredSailor Propofol! In last 15-years I've had two endoscopies, three colonoscopies, a cardiac conversion, and prostate biopsy under the divine sedation of Propofol (Diprivan). Out like a light for five to 30-minutes and then suddenly awake and it's all over with no memory, pain, or agitation. I can think of no reason to have those somewhat unpleasant procedures done while fully conscious. As far as taking action now - I too am a action person who makes extensive decision trees prior to major life events, or even some minor ones. What to do, after the DRE, MRI, 4KScore, Free PSA tests was driving me crazy, literally CRAZY! I couldn't sleep, I could not concentrate, and found myself obsessing over diagnosis probabilities and treatment modalities. My MO hit me over the head several times and smacked me in the face once with "I've done this thousands of times, I've helped men down this road many times a month for over 25-years and really do know what I am doing. SO - please let me guide you as we get more information." He stressed that NO Decisions of any kind were necessary, in fact would not be appropriate, prior to getting the biopsy information back. He then stressed "I've never lost a patient, EVER, due to being cautious and taking our time to make an informed decision." He worked hard to make sure that I could talk with him as much as I wished after the biopsy as we then formulated a plan to deal with the biopsy results. He also told me that I would probably want to talk with other medical professionals about the biopsy results, e.g radiation guys, maybe HIFU proponents, and even, hopefully, active surveillance advocates. His main takeaway was that PCa treatment is complex and can take many unexpected twists and turns. All we, the patient, can do is take one more step with the one more bit of information we gain. Step -by- Step without looking too far into the future. It is a hard lesson - to take this journey step by step, but, at least in my case with my mental attitude, looking too far into the future is counter productive. And, I did learn that my MO really did anticipate ALL my questions and concerns and provided almost all the information I wanted and needed without me asking for it. I understand how Michael Jackson got hooked on propofol. Its the only rest I get. I joked with the last doc that used it to put me under, do the procedure and then go to lunch. Wake me mid afternoon. ðŸ˜€ Thanks for the information. I always said cancer was the worst thing I could have to deal with because of my tendency to worry. But here I am hoping for a hat trick on these tests.

Patience? Patience? Aint nobody got time for that! ðŸ˜€ They are going to target the pirads 3-4, I presume they will hit it in several places since its 5mm and we know the MRI is inaccurate. After they are done they will do a 12 core random. My thought is Im asleep for this one, do everything you can while Im asleep. I do not think that I will be able to be still enough for the biopsy for the precision they needed.

Posts.Title: Diagnosis question

Posts.Content: Hi guys and gals, Maybe this thread will help others but I know it could help me. Im having my fusion biopsy on 2/13 and I want to be prepared for the results and have some well thought out questions ready. I dont know if the results will come over the phone or in person but I know I cannot wait until my next scheduled appointment on 3/29. If just inflammation or prostatitis as suggested by the MRI (please Lord let it be that) then I will have had two random 12 cores plus the fusion biopsy of the pirads 3-4 all of which were clean. My thinking is that there would really be nothing else we can do but monitor PSA and redo the MRI. Am I missing anything I should ask for or some other treatment plan for what would be a continued BPH diagnosis? If its pca obviously I will need the Gleason score. But thats where everything gets confusing and I know that many answers will depend on the Gleason score. Is there any extended information I should ask for? Do I ask for a second opinion on the scoring? I keep seeing people talking about the Cleveland Clinic, do I ask for a referral there? Second opinion on how to proceed? Ill be a little lost if this is the disagnosis. Any tidbits of information from your experience that can help me in the event of either path? Im thinking your stories and tips might help me in whats likely to be great news or bad news. Thanks in advance

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by JJO The big worry seems to be infections. Any hint of a fever and I'd rush to the doctor/hospital. With blood, I usually give it a day or two and hope it turns brown. That usually means it's on the way out. My last biopsy I had red blood in my urine for 3-5 days; brown for close to two weeks. Everything worked out fine. Yep my temps have been a steady 97.7, so Im good there. I think that the pressure of needing to go badly for an hour (thank you Atlanta traffic) just reopened the wounds.

Posts.Content: Im a key lime pie guy but I agree benign is great. I havent actually had an MRI of any kind, thats kind of what Im wondering if I shouldnt go ahead and get the one thats coupled with the high heat ultrasound. If no cancer, great but while in there maybe they can zap some of the BPH tissue to relieve what little urinary symptoms Im having? This is more of an ART than a science it seems and while I really want to rest easily in these results, I dont want to let some small unseen cancer grow. So whats the consensus, ask for the MRI?
Posts.Title: PCA3 came back...some help from someone who has been there done that?

Posts.Content: Yep that was my assessment....darned if I do and darned if I dont. Obviously, if my body were to restart its own t production....well theres nothing that can be done about that. It is what it is. But it appears from the docs perspective hrt is permanently off the table becausebest caseit will fuel the growth of my bph (presuming cancer isnt ever found or develops). My 12 core was all perfectly negative. I guess I could go back on hrt if my own levels do not rebound and then talk to the doctor about one of the bph treatments to alleviate the symptoms caused by the t fueled bph growth. The doc said the t probably just increased the curve on which my prostate was already growing. But Im only 47 ...almost 48 years old. Thats a lot of possible future growth. If cancer ever develops I would probablygiven my prostate is already 46ml+opt to try the removal with surgery. At least then I could guarantee no future spreading (or relatively guarantee it) and go back on hrt without worry. Id probably go back using the shots as the gel is a giant pain in the butt. Well I guess it could be worse for sure but after the high of the good test result from my biopsy, I feel like crap now. I need to be able to exercise and do simple walking. Fortunately, Im an Accountant so my work doesnt depend on physical abilities. Thanks for the reply!

Posts.Title: Well it appears I am not immortal....testosterone related

Posts.Content: 48 and my PSA spiked to 4.1 in March. Free PSA measured above the threshold they wanted so we did a biopsy and I had a perfect 12 for 0 on the cancer free. Fast forward six months to my checkup and total PSA measured 4.4 and they did the pca3 test to see if I had the genes. I still have not talked to the doctor about the results but was told by office staff that it was negative. So having not had a conversation with the doctor yet, what should I push for? -remeasure in six months and see because it is likely just BPH? -go ahead and ask for the MRI to be sure theres no cancer? -lean down, put my head between my legs and kiss my Kiester goodbye? -go have some pie? I just dont knowhaving seen the long road of benign results you guys have had only to find cancer laterif I should rest comfortably in the negative pca3. Thoughts?

Posts.Title: PCA3 came back...some help from someone who has been there done that?

Posts.Content: BPH was the diagnosis from the first round of tests and the biopsy. The biopsy showed inflammation as best I can remember. We stopped the testosterone replacement and I had hoped my PSA would stabilize. .3 rise in only six months correlated to a faster rise in a year than I was increasing before stopping testosterone and the biopsy. Im just wondering why its still increasing. Im going to switch doctors to the same practice but a doctor my dad uses. Hes 5 minutes down the road instead of 30 miles away through traffic. This guy is very very good as well so I will discuss it with him. I just worry my story will end up in a long signature history that ends with cancer. I guess if I live long enough thats nearly a guarantee. I , more precisely, dont want us to miss an aggressive cancer.

Posts.Title: PCA3 came back...some help from someone who has been there done that?

Posts.Content: Hi guys and gals! Its been a while since Ive posted, after my pc scare of March, subsequent biopsy and negative results. I really liked my doctor for the pc treatment, not so sure about his knowledge of managing hormones. I stopped juicing with the Androgel (after 10 years) on 3/6 and my doctors said that whatever negative impacts (aka the crash) I would see should manifest themselves within a couple weeks...certainly by a month. Well I cruised right by that with relative minimal issues. Fatigue and stupidity (beyond whats normal ) were my main complaints but thought I could fight through. Now that Im essentially at 3 months later Im sweating and missing my testosterone. I think Ive bottomed out. Mainly fatigue, low libido, lack of concentration and drive (just looking at a project on the House is mentally overwhelming) and some fleeting depression. But worst is extreme exercise intollerance, shortness of breath and anxiety. The anxiety manifests itself in the form of feeling like Im going to explode from the inside of my chest out. Ive been doing the same walk for years now, sometimes twice a day but had to call my wife to pick me up yesterday because I was too exhausted to put one foot in front of the other and was having trouble breathing. I was about 15 minutes from the end of the walk but still, I used to do that walk with ease. I take Xanax as needed and the Xanax will take away the shortness of breath and anxiety so I know its not heart related. It was hot and I have developed asthma in the last year so that might have contributed. Breathing has definitely gotten worse since stopping the t. So heres my question.....what have you guys on HT done when the doc says gotta stop because of pc or the threat of pc. I cant live like this....Im gaining weight because I cant exercise. My follow up isnt until September but I think Ill end up spontaneously angry combusting before then. No not really, probably! ðŸ˜. I have noticed that the size of my testicles have doubled since stopping the HT, so I was hoping my body was starting my own testosterone up again. Now Im unsure. Anyone with experience? Sorry for the length of this.
Posts.Title: Well it appears I am not immortal....testosterone related

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by white08gt Talk to your Uro about trying Clomid, side effect is increases your natural testosterone. after one month of taking my T doubled from low 200s to low 400s. waiting for my followup 6 month checkup and anxious to see if it has come up considerable or just leveled out. worth looking into, insurance will not pay for it but only $42 at Costco for 30 day supply. clomiphene citrate, clomid for short. check it out on the web. Well after typing out this long post and then reading your reply, I was kind of struck in the face by reality and how dumb my original post wasI blame the low T. Im totally screwed. And I just realized it. The pc scare of fueling pc, if its there, by using testosterone isnt that the increased risk is a side effect of Androgel specifically, its a side effect of the testosterone itself. So whether I get my numbers up by my own body rebounding, through clomid or by restarting hrt it increases my odds of fueling pc or fueling the bhp that I was diagnosed with. You know in movies when a character realizes theyre screwed right before a train or car or speeding bullet hits them and they look at the camera with an oh crap look? I just had my moment. Dang..... I guess my only hope is that my own body rebounds with just enough of its own testosterone that the symptoms of low t become manageable. If not, there is no permanent solution except to have the prostate taken out so that I can restart hrt without the fear of pc or without swelling my prostate to the size of a grapefruit. Its already 46 ml! Thanks for the reply. Ill discuss this with my doc. But it seems like a problem with no answer.
Posts.Title: Well it appears I am not immortal....testosterone related

Posts.Content: This board has been invaluable for helping me understand the ins and outs of pca. Great advice and great people. I find that the psychology of it all is quite interesting. I alternate between pfffft this is nothing to this is eternally hopeless. Sometimes within the same hour. Yes, I know I have just a slight case of pca so far but that can change and still has had a big impact on lifes uncertainty and various avenues of life. Sex to career ambition and focus...relationships, etc. It doesnt help that it seems that everything else in life: work, finances, sons college grades, etc. are all spinning out of control at the same time. The weather is getting nice here so Im hoping to get out a lot more and exercise, which will greatly help. Maybe we can all pitch in ideas about how you cope with this mess we find ourselves in. Maybe we can help someone focus and be aware of the mental health aspect of this crappy disease.

N/A 3/18 4.1 PSA at 48 YO. u/s measured 46 ml prostate 3/18free PSA 10% 3/1812 core all negative 9/18 4.5 PSA 9/18 negative pca3 12/18- 4K at 17% 12/18- 3t MRI, 5mm pirads 3-4 and a pirads 1-2 2/19- Fusion biopsy. G6 (3+3) 20% of a single core AS for now 4/19-PSA at 7.21 (up from 4.5 in September 2018! Gulp
Posts.Title: The psychology of pca

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by OldTiredSailor I've described my coping process in other threads here but will try to briefly cover MY way of dealing with the fundamental life changes you describe. I do understand a bit of your anguish about the many changes occurring in short order. For me, and my wife of 44-years: - sudden onset of seemingly serious heart problems after years of being told those problems would never be important - now need to take medicine to control heart rhythms, which adversely affects ALL my athletic endeavors - wife suffered two life threatening and debilitating bicycle accidents which now prevent her from riding with me, which has been a very important part of our life for over 35-years - wife went thru five serious orthopedic surgeries in three years in attempt to repair shoulder, arm, hip, leg with not so good results - move from San Diego to SW Florida and all the changes (good and bad) that entails - owning a home for the first time in 18-years (had been living on our sailboat since mid-2000) - termination of relationship with sister after death of our parents and her theft of several hundred K dollars from the estate (she was executrix) - wife retired from a job she loved and had worked at for 35-years and found she really missed the work and friends (now 2,800 miles distant) My wife and I have been a strong team since 1974. We've gone thru a lot of counseling as a couple and as individuals. I did graduate work in counseling and she had some undergraduate classes in the same while studying to be a speech therapist and special ed teacher. Our prior experiences were not sufficient to get us through the trauma, physical and mental of all the changes, gravely exacerbated by my PCa diagnosis and treatment, since 2014. I was fortunate to find a Ph.D counselor with vast experience dealing with geriatric patients (I am 71 and wife is 63) experiencing fundamental changes due to physical and mental situations. She is in her mid-50s and is personally aware of many of the situations we here deal with. And, her 78-year old father has been battling PCa for 10-years (RP, ADT, radiation, metastatic disease) so she really understands the PCa aspects of our problems. She is the primary care giver for her father and has also counselled hundreds of other PCa men. While I was in the pre-RP, post-RP, and 'wait for the first post-RP ÂµPSA' phase of my PCa journey I talked with her twice a week for a hour each time. I did not have to explain things - I could just vent with no concern about her feelings or judgement. That in itself was of great value but she was able to ask questions and turn around my statements and thoughts to allow me to understand what I was really worried about and what I really wanted to do. Additionally, due to her personal experience with her father, and with many dozen other PCa men, she had a lot of practical advice and was quite outspoken in offering it. And, she arranged for my wife and I to meet with a couples therapist who specializes in medical counselling and practical strategies for dealing with traumatic medical issues. I did not appreciate the degree of PTSD my wife was suffering after the two horrible bike accidents (2014 - she had to walk two miles out of a mountain canyon with a broken arm, dislocated shoulder, and severe concussion & 2016 she was unconscious for 6-days). That accident built on the PTSD she suffered 30-years ago when she had to walk 3-miles out of the Mt. Rainier woods with a broken illiac crest, broken forearm, and concussion. I was shocked at how little I understood where my wife was coming from and why she was being so cold about my whole PCa journey. The couples therapist was able to let wife and I understand and appreciate the others perspective on my PCa. I just did not know how freaked out the wife was about my disease. She was unable to talk about it until after the RP and was unable to say the word "cancer" until months after we began sessions with the counselor. My therapist also convinced me to try some anti-depressants and some anti-anxiety medication which, after a short while, allowed me to develop and practice new thought processes. I now understand that: - PCa is a 'rest of my lifetime' disease and will always be lurking in the background. - I am doing everything possible to manage my PCa - I will take the required next steps, whatever they are, if I suffer BCR - I can't do anything more than I am now doing - I cannot change my place in life - I must actively find things to do that give my life purpose and meaning - I discuss all my fears and worries with the wife who can now accept that I do have cancer Thank you for the post, exactly what I had in mind. Respect to the two of you for going through all of that and coming out the other side. I think Im sitting at a 70% everything else and 30% pca frustration level right now. Hopefully everything else will smooth out so I can move on to other things. I was just surprised by the variability of that frustration. Yes I have a low grade of cancer, yeay me, but its affecting my life pretty significantly.

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Southsider Prostate cancer is long trip, and it afflicts old men. Even an aggressive , metastatic PC,often takes a lot long time. Usually gives the patients a long time to stew in their juices. That's the reason why this subforum is the most popular at "cancer forums". A lot of other cancers are sprints, this is a marathon. All valid points, thank you

Posts.Title: The psychology of pca

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by andy12 Yes, of course, anything can change at any time. A meteor could fall out of the sky and knock your head off. Do you spend a lot of time worrying about that? I think the way we play the cards we are dealt is less about the psychology of pca and more about the psychology of us, as individuals. I have a similar diagnosis to yours, four years now. I have explicit trust in my doctor and continue on AS. My PSA has never been higher than the 4.2 that triggered the biopsy (along with family history--brother) in 2015. Most recently, last month, it was 2.5. I really don't think much about cancer. I live in a pleasant climate, I am fit and healthy, I have wonderful grandchildren that make me smile and laugh. I know that hearing the word "cancer" is frightening. But as we hear over and over on this forum, prostate cancer when caught early is very treatable, even curable. I had a neighbor who had radical prostatectomy when he was 51. He died last fall at the age of 81 from heart disease. It really sounds like your doctor and you are ahead of the curve on your situation. That is a good thing. If the meteor is coming at you, you will see it well in advance. Yes, get outside and exercise. And then, do it some more. Funny you should mention a meteor, Ive often said that if I had my choice of how to go, getting dead centered by a meteor would be quick, painless and newsworthy! ðŸ˜€ I dont think its as simple as you State. Youre coming at it from a different perspective and clarity, having the benefit of time with it. This is a month old for me, not quite that (although Ive been in the testing loop for a year). Unfortunately, we dont go through this in a vacuum. I think if I could get everything else to stop falling apart of once, Id be in decent shape. Im managing this pca and several life adjustments all at the same time. Its hard not to feel like youre being hit with a tsunami at times. So we have exercise and life distractions (grandkids). I dont want any grandkids right now though, my kids are 20 and 16!

Posts.Title: The psychology of pca

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by DjinTonic Hi ISZ. Areas found on the MRI are graded from 1 to 5 on a PIRADS scale. Here is an explanation of the likelihood of an area being PCa. When a biopsy is planned the usual 12 cores taken around the prostate are increased in number to include the PIRADS 3 to 5 areas. 3 is an Indeterminate or "gray" zone, but it's considered best to explore those too. In a biopsy-naive guy, which you are not, a doc who suspects PCa will go ahead with the biopsy even if the MRI comes back as negative. See what the MRI shows and what you doc says and keep us updated. Outstanding thank you. I almost deleted the post for it being a dumb question but turns out it wasnt. Im more prepared thank you very much!
Posts.Title: 3t MRI test results back tomorrow

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by DjinTonic OK, as you have learned, your MRI merits a biopsy, which becomes the "bible" for what comes after. You'll know what the PIRADS 3/4 lesions is. If it turns out to be nothing or scar tissue, you now have a baseline MRI for comparison if there are future concerns. If it is cancer, either you will be a candidate for AS, or, if it needs treatment, you have caught it early. Early diagnosis is the best way to get the upper hand on PCa! Good luck -- and keep us posted. Thanks for the reply. This is the most aggravating condition ever known to man. No answers just more tests. Im not sure exactly what he thought was good news exactly...maybe other than I wasnt eaten up and the spots werent 5s.

Posts.Title: 3t MRI test results back tomorrow

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by DjinTonic You're welcome. I was still editing when you replied! Thanks. My PSA has been rising since being measured but my pcp throught it was incidental to testosterone replacement. Finally got above 4 in March of last year. Free was like 10%. Biopsy was negative for all 12. My prostate is 46ml so they thought it was just BPH due to a honker of a prostate. The thing is I have absolutely no symptoms of any kind. Maybe Ill get up 1x a night if I drink water before bed, most nights I dont. I switched docs who tested the 4K that came back as 17% so here we are. I predict all 3s so that we dont know what to do. Im really hoping and praying for nothing found. Not sure what to expect, very aggravated and tired. Posts.Title: 3t MRI test results back tomorrow

Posts.Content: So as to not be a total attention whore and start a new thread....Im posting the highlights or lowlights from my MRI below: It is Enlarged 5.8 x 4.1 x 4.4 CM Two findings: 1) Wedge shaped area of ill defined decreased T2 signal within the right peripheral zone of the mid gland. Associated with a slightly more nodular area of more focal T2 hypointense signal measuring 5MM . There is also mid focal volume loss, mild to moderate decreased signal on ADC map and equivocal increased signal on DWI (and I dont even drink! ). This area is hyperenhancing on the DCE (PI-RADS 3/4). 2) Ill-defined area of low t2 signal within the left anterior peripheral zone of the prostatic apex abutting the border with the transitional zone, with mild decreased signal on ADC (PI-RADS 2). Transitional zone: Diffuse heterogeneous signal throughout the transitional zone which appears to be aggravated into more defined areas of nodule signal intensity, most consistent with stromal predominant hyperplastic change (PI-RADS 2)..I guess this is the #2 item above? The outer postatatic capsule is somewhat indistinct at the level of the PI-RADS4 lesion mentioned above. No bulky measurable extracapsular disease identified. No pathologically enlarged lymph nodes. There are a few mildly prominent external lilac chain lymph nodes present with normal appearing central fatty hila. So the finding per the report: Suspicious area of signal abnormality within the right peripheral zone of the mid gland (PI-RADS 3 / 4) morphologically suggesting scarring/fibrosis related to prior prostatitis VERSES underlying neoplasm. Consider targeted biopsy vs follow-up imaging. No additional areas of suspicious signal abnormality within the prostate glandbut what about the PI-RADS2 above? Is that not suspicious? Aforementioned are of signal abnormality abuts the prostate capsule, which is slightly retracted. No bulky extracapsular disease or findings of metastatic disease within the pelvis. So my takeaways: After hearing the 3 / 4 I honestly had a hard time processing information. That was like a kick to the gut. But what I took away from the doc was: -5mm is small and caught very early no matter even if it is cancer, which it might not be. -Were doing a focused biopsy on 2/14 -If it is cancer, treatment depends on the type. Non aggressive cancerwe might just AS it. AggressiveIll probably want it out of me using the high frequency ultrasound. It sounds like the report indicates it thinks the HI-RADS 3 / 4 is something other than cancer. It seems to show that Im not eaten up with cancer. My doc was glad to see whatever it is was confined to the prostate but Im having a hard time getting that from the results aboveit looks to me like its within the prostate but pretty darned close to not being in the prostate. Somehow my doctor said this was all good news. Aside from proving Im not totally eaten up wit cancer this just seems to kick the can down the road for more expensive tests. We might ultimately prove its not cancer but I dont see this as good news. Any help? Thanks as always guys and gals.

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by DjinTonic OK, as you have learned, your MRI merits a biopsy, which becomes the "bible" for what comes after. You'll know what the PIRADS 3/4 lesions is. If it turns out to be nothing or scar tissue, you now have a baseline MRI for comparison if there are future concerns. If it is cancer, either you will be a candidate for AS, or, if it needs treatment, you have caught it early. Early diagnosis is the best way to get the upper hand on PCa! Good luck -- and keep us posted. Thanks for the reply. This is the most aggravating condition ever known to man. No answers just more tests. Im not sure exactly what he thought was good news exactly...maybe other than I wasnt eaten up and the spots werent 5s.

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by andy12 Yes, of course, anything can change at any time. A meteor could fall out of the sky and knock your head off. Do you spend a lot of time worrying about that? I think the way we play the cards we are dealt is less about the psychology of pca and more about the psychology of us, as individuals. I have a similar diagnosis to yours, four years now. I have explicit trust in my doctor and continue on AS. My PSA has never been higher than the 4.2 that triggered the biopsy (along with family history--brother) in 2015. Most recently, last month, it was 2.5. I really don't think much about cancer. I live in a pleasant climate, I am fit and healthy, I have wonderful grandchildren that make me smile and laugh. I know that hearing the word "cancer" is frightening. But as we hear over and over on this forum, prostate cancer when caught early is very treatable, even curable. I had a neighbor who had radical prostatectomy when he was 51. He died last fall at the age of 81 from heart disease. It really sounds like your doctor and you are ahead of the curve on your situation. That is a good thing. If the meteor is coming at you, you will see it well in advance. Yes, get outside and exercise. And then, do it some more. Funny you should mention a meteor, Ive often said that if I had my choice of how to go, getting dead centered by a meteor would be quick, painless and newsworthy! ðŸ˜€ I dont think its as simple as you State. Youre coming at it from a different perspective and clarity, having the benefit of time with it. This is a month old for me, not quite that (although Ive been in the testing loop for a year). Unfortunately, we dont go through this in a vacuum. I think if I could get everything else to stop falling apart of once, Id be in decent shape. Im managing this pca and several life adjustments all at the same time. Its hard not to feel like youre being hit with a tsunami at times. So we have exercise and life distractions (grandkids). I dont want any grandkids right now though, my kids are 20 and 16!

Posts.Title: The psychology of pca

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by OldTiredSailor I've described my coping process in other threads here but will try to briefly cover MY way of dealing with the fundamental life changes you describe. I do understand a bit of your anguish about the many changes occurring in short order. For me, and my wife of 44-years: - sudden onset of seemingly serious heart problems after years of being told those problems would never be important - now need to take medicine to control heart rhythms, which adversely affects ALL my athletic endeavors - wife suffered two life threatening and debilitating bicycle accidents which now prevent her from riding with me, which has been a very important part of our life for over 35-years - wife went thru five serious orthopedic surgeries in three years in attempt to repair shoulder, arm, hip, leg with not so good results - move from San Diego to SW Florida and all the changes (good and bad) that entails - owning a home for the first time in 18-years (had been living on our sailboat since mid-2000) - termination of relationship with sister after death of our parents and her theft of several hundred K dollars from the estate (she was executrix) - wife retired from a job she loved and had worked at for 35-years and found she really missed the work and friends (now 2,800 miles distant) My wife and I have been a strong team since 1974. We've gone thru a lot of counseling as a couple and as individuals. I did graduate work in counseling and she had some undergraduate classes in the same while studying to be a speech therapist and special ed teacher. Our prior experiences were not sufficient to get us through the trauma, physical and mental of all the changes, gravely exacerbated by my PCa diagnosis and treatment, since 2014. I was fortunate to find a Ph.D counselor with vast experience dealing with geriatric patients (I am 71 and wife is 63) experiencing fundamental changes due to physical and mental situations. She is in her mid-50s and is personally aware of many of the situations we here deal with. And, her 78-year old father has been battling PCa for 10-years (RP, ADT, radiation, metastatic disease) so she really understands the PCa aspects of our problems. She is the primary care giver for her father and has also counselled hundreds of other PCa men. While I was in the pre-RP, post-RP, and 'wait for the first post-RP ÂµPSA' phase of my PCa journey I talked with her twice a week for a hour each time. I did not have to explain things - I could just vent with no concern about her feelings or judgement. That in itself was of great value but she was able to ask questions and turn around my statements and thoughts to allow me to understand what I was really worried about and what I really wanted to do. Additionally, due to her personal experience with her father, and with many dozen other PCa men, she had a lot of practical advice and was quite outspoken in offering it. And, she arranged for my wife and I to meet with a couples therapist who specializes in medical counselling and practical strategies for dealing with traumatic medical issues. I did not appreciate the degree of PTSD my wife was suffering after the two horrible bike accidents (2014 - she had to walk two miles out of a mountain canyon with a broken arm, dislocated shoulder, and severe concussion & 2016 she was unconscious for 6-days). That accident built on the PTSD she suffered 30-years ago when she had to walk 3-miles out of the Mt. Rainier woods with a broken illiac crest, broken forearm, and concussion. I was shocked at how little I understood where my wife was coming from and why she was being so cold about my whole PCa journey. The couples therapist was able to let wife and I understand and appreciate the others perspective on my PCa. I just did not know how freaked out the wife was about my disease. She was unable to talk about it until after the RP and was unable to say the word "cancer" until months after we began sessions with the counselor. My therapist also convinced me to try some anti-depressants and some anti-anxiety medication which, after a short while, allowed me to develop and practice new thought processes. I now understand that: - PCa is a 'rest of my lifetime' disease and will always be lurking in the background. - I am doing everything possible to manage my PCa - I will take the required next steps, whatever they are, if I suffer BCR - I can't do anything more than I am now doing - I cannot change my place in life - I must actively find things to do that give my life purpose and meaning - I discuss all my fears and worries with the wife who can now accept that I do have cancer Thank you for the post, exactly what I had in mind. Respect to the two of you for going through all of that and coming out the other side. I think Im sitting at a 70% everything else and 30% pca frustration level right now. Hopefully everything else will smooth out so I can move on to other things. I was just surprised by the variability of that frustration. Yes I have a low grade of cancer, yeay me, but its affecting my life pretty significantly.

Posts.Title: 3t MRI test results back tomorrow

Posts.Content: So as to not be a total attention whore and start a new thread....Im posting the highlights or lowlights from my MRI below: It is Enlarged 5.8 x 4.1 x 4.4 CM Two findings: 1) Wedge shaped area of ill defined decreased T2 signal within the right peripheral zone of the mid gland. Associated with a slightly more nodular area of more focal T2 hypointense signal measuring 5MM . There is also mid focal volume loss, mild to moderate decreased signal on ADC map and equivocal increased signal on DWI (and I dont even drink! ). This area is hyperenhancing on the DCE (PI-RADS 3/4). 2) Ill-defined area of low t2 signal within the left anterior peripheral zone of the prostatic apex abutting the border with the transitional zone, with mild decreased signal on ADC (PI-RADS 2). Transitional zone: Diffuse heterogeneous signal throughout the transitional zone which appears to be aggravated into more defined areas of nodule signal intensity, most consistent with stromal predominant hyperplastic change (PI-RADS 2)..I guess this is the #2 item above? The outer postatatic capsule is somewhat indistinct at the level of the PI-RADS4 lesion mentioned above. No bulky measurable extracapsular disease identified. No pathologically enlarged lymph nodes. There are a few mildly prominent external lilac chain lymph nodes present with normal appearing central fatty hila. So the finding per the report: Suspicious area of signal abnormality within the right peripheral zone of the mid gland (PI-RADS 3 / 4) morphologically suggesting scarring/fibrosis related to prior prostatitis VERSES underlying neoplasm. Consider targeted biopsy vs follow-up imaging. No additional areas of suspicious signal abnormality within the prostate glandbut what about the PI-RADS2 above? Is that not suspicious? Aforementioned are of signal abnormality abuts the prostate capsule, which is slightly retracted. No bulky extracapsular disease or findings of metastatic disease within the pelvis. So my takeaways: After hearing the 3 / 4 I honestly had a hard time processing information. That was like a kick to the gut. But what I took away from the doc was: -5mm is small and caught very early no matter even if it is cancer, which it might not be. -Were doing a focused biopsy on 2/14 -If it is cancer, treatment depends on the type. Non aggressive cancerwe might just AS it. AggressiveIll probably want it out of me using the high frequency ultrasound. It sounds like the report indicates it thinks the HI-RADS 3 / 4 is something other than cancer. It seems to show that Im not eaten up with cancer. My doc was glad to see whatever it is was confined to the prostate but Im having a hard time getting that from the results aboveit looks to me like its within the prostate but pretty darned close to not being in the prostate. Somehow my doctor said this was all good news. Aside from proving Im not totally eaten up wit cancer this just seems to kick the can down the road for more expensive tests. We might ultimately prove its not cancer but I dont see this as good news. Any help? Thanks as always guys and gals.

This area is hyperenhancing on the DCE (PI-RADS 3/4). 2) Ill-defined area of low t2 signal within the left anterior peripheral zone of the prostatic apex abutting the border with the transitional zone, with mild decreased signal on ADC (PI-RADS 2). Transitional zone: Diffuse heterogeneous signal throughout the transitional zone which appears to be aggravated into more defined areas of nodule signal intensity, most consistent with stromal predominant hyperplastic change (PI-RADS 2)..I guess this is the #2 item above? The outer postatatic capsule is somewhat indistinct at the level of the PI-RADS4 lesion mentioned above. No bulky measurable extracapsular disease identified. No pathologically enlarged lymph nodes. There are a few mildly prominent external lilac chain lymph nodes present with normal appearing central fatty hila. So the finding per the report: Suspicious area of signal abnormality within the right peripheral zone of the mid gland (PI-RADS 3 / 4) morphologically suggesting scarring/fibrosis related to prior prostatitis VERSES underlying neoplasm. Consider targeted biopsy vs follow-up imaging. No additional areas of suspicious signal abnormality within the prostate glandbut what about the PI-RADS2 above? Is that not suspicious? Aforementioned are of signal abnormality abuts the prostate capsule, which is slightly retracted. No bulky extracapsular disease or findings of metastatic disease within the pelvis. So my takeaways: After hearing the 3 / 4 I honestly had a hard time processing information. That was like a kick to the gut. But what I took away from the doc was: -5mm is small and caught very early no matter even if it is cancer, which it might not be. -Were doing a focused biopsy on 2/14 -If it is cancer, treatment depends on the type. Non aggressive cancerwe might just AS it. AggressiveIll probably want it out of me using the high frequency ultrasound. It sounds like the report indicates it thinks the HI-RADS 3 / 4 is something other than cancer. It seems to show that Im not eaten up with cancer. My doc was glad to see whatever it is was confined to the prostate but Im having a hard time getting that from the results aboveit looks to me like its within the prostate but pretty darned close to not being in the prostate. Somehow my doctor said this was all good news. Aside from proving Im not totally eaten up wit cancer this just seems to kick the can down the road for more expensive tests. We might ultimately prove its not cancer but I dont see this as good news. Any help? Thanks as always guys and gals.

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by DjinTonic OK, as you have learned, your MRI merits a biopsy, which becomes the "bible" for what comes after. You'll know what the PIRADS 3/4 lesions is. If it turns out to be nothing or scar tissue, you now have a baseline MRI for comparison if there are future concerns. If it is cancer, either you will be a candidate for AS, or, if it needs treatment, you have caught it early. Early diagnosis is the best way to get the upper hand on PCa! Good luck -- and keep us posted. Thanks for the reply. This is the most aggravating condition ever known to man. No answers just more tests. Im not sure exactly what he thought was good news exactly...maybe other than I wasnt eaten up and the spots werent 5s.

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by DjinTonic For what it's worth, I had no symptoms during the early years of my BHP, just a rising PSA that prompted a long series of biopsies. It's quite possible the MRI results will shed light on what's going on. Stay positive! 46 g -- that's small potatoes (well, one potato). My prostate was 90 g when I had my TURP surgery to scoop it out. It was reduced to 30 g. It had grown back to 60 g at the time of my RP for PCa. (The specific gravity of prostate tissue is about 1, so 1 ml = 1 g). Wow! 90g you have me beat. I thought from the way the docs are talking that 46 must have been a world record or something! Turns out no. Thanks for the info and best of luck to you!

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by DjinTonic Hi ISZ. Areas found on the MRI are graded from 1 to 5 on a PIRADS scale. Here is an explanation of the likelihood of an area being PCa. When a biopsy is planned the usual 12 cores taken around the prostate are increased in number to include the PIRADS 3 to 5 areas. 3 is an Indeterminate or "gray" zone, but it's considered best to explore those too. In a biopsy-naive guy, which you are not, a doc who suspects PCa will go ahead with the biopsy even if the MRI comes back as negative. See what the MRI shows and what you doc says and keep us updated. Outstanding thank you. I almost deleted the post for it being a dumb question but turns out it wasnt. Im more prepared thank you very much!

Posts.Title: Circle of life

Posts.Content: Hi guys just wanted to let you guys know about something that has helped with my BPH symptoms that werent really bad to begin with. After my PSA rise and subsequent biopsy, it looks like its just BPH at this time. But I did have some mild symptomsup peeing at night once and sometimes my stream would be like a fire hose and sometimes more like a garden hose on mist (had to push up into the urinal at work to keep from spraying the guy standing next to me at the other urinal ). At the insistence of my niece I just had to try turmeric curcininium to shrink the prostate and help. After six months nothing changed except my wallet got lighter. Ill be stopping that as soon as I swallow the remainder that I bought. However two weeks ago I reluctantly tried Saw Palmetto. After my scare, the doc ripped me off the testosterone replacement and my soldier of sex was surrendering mid battle. I tried saw palmetto and I know it worked because I was peeved about the cost and expected nothing from it. I thought This crap isnt going to work, but it did! Libido definitely increased. Sexual function improved slightly. Urine stream definitely increased and I can even increase the stream by squeezing or doing a keigel exercise. Previously for the last untold number of years I was a gravity controlled machine. I now generally go through the night without even getting up, although I still might if I drank a lot of water before bed or had a later dinner. So I you have BPH or PCa that causes flow issues give it a shot. I take two 450s a day. Instructions say to take Four a day but thats too expensive and probably unnecessary for me. Good luck fellas.
Posts.Title: Saw palmetto

Posts.Content: Im discontinuing the turmeric because I ran out and never got any benefit from it. I actually took the saw palmetto for the libido issues that have been showing up. However, the increased urine flow and improvement of nighttime trips to the toilet is real. I didnt know that was supposed to happen. Placebo or not, its improved. Ill see how it continues:

Posts.Title: Second Pathology Opinion

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Michael F Hi doubleH! Very glad to see that you PSA has dropped since your arrival at The Forum! Since you are on AS, when is your next scheduled Bx? We previously had a discussion about getting a 3T MRI in advance of your next Bx. This would be wise in order to identify and target any areas of suspicion that may have been missed on your 1st Bx. Your PSA is still quite elevated and any "undetected" PCa should be ruled in or out (hopefully out!). If your next Bx is on the near horizon, sending your 1st set Bx slides to Dr Epstein's group for a 2nd evaluation may not be of any clinical value. If me, I'd wait for the next Bx and evaluate the results. If there is uncertainty about continuing AS, I would send the slides to Dr Epstein. Meanwhile, keep that PSA decreasing! MF MichaelF, You pointed out something which I thought was impossible. How does PSA ever go down? Besides prostatitis or infection? I thought my doc said that the prostate would never naturally shrink and therefore my PSA would be elevated and never really go down. I suppose I could have misheard him.

Posts.Content: Absolutely...Dr. Epsteins group at Johns Hopkins. Mine were reviewed and it changed my diagnosis from precancerous to cancer. What possible reason would there be to not do it? Go for it I say. If nothing changes you have extra assurance of one of the premier pathologists looking at it. Sounds like were nearly the same, 3+3 with a single 20% here.

Posts.Title: Second Pathology Opinion

Posts.Content: Of course it does. The higher you affluenceall other things being equalthe higher the odds you are doing your annual checkups and getting tested for various things. The more affluent you are the greater the chance youre going to be educated and able to make the best decision for your health. Generally before I go into a doctors office Im generally educated on why Im there, the treatment options and am already talking next steps and what ifs with the doctor. For me my PSA was found to be high during a routine physical, I had no idea of the issue until that day.

I wish my urologist had told me the same thing, about two years earlier. My cancer might not have progressed as it did, while he led me believe that my prostate was normal. As you've been at this for six months (?) ... I don't see any stats other than your PSA, I'm guessing that you are in the same boat I was in four years ago... consistently rising PSA but all tests "negative" so far. If my urologist had offered me a prostatectomy back then I might have taken him up on it, rather than fumbling around with false negative biopsies which were doomed to failure unless a different approach was taken. Of course, standards of care wouldn't permit that. Whatever loop you find yourself currently caught up in, I hope you can find an exit soon! I added my stats but the dont show up in my signature. March PSA hit 4.1 but Ive been high since 2012 age adjusted. Urologist said I should have had my first biopsy in 2013. Free was 10% so we did a 12 core that all came back cancer free, just inflammation. The prostate is 47ml. Stopped testosterone replacement in March hoping that would stop the increase but the PSA went to 4.5. Now the 4K is 17%.
