Posts.Title: Continuing my saga

Posts.Content: Well, its been a while since I last updated. It seems that Im stuck in the cycle like it or not. My last appointment my PSA went up slightly to 4.4 or 4.5. So my doctor ordered the 4k PSA test that came back at 17%. Not great but also not 94%. So im now on to the 3t prostate ultrasound. That test willaccording to my doctoronly show clinically significant cancers. So a small piece of low grade cancer in there will likely not get picked up by the MRI. If something is picked up on the MRI, I get the fun of the MRI guided ultrasound. But it sounds like there is nothing that will ever rule out that I have cancer, it looks like were just delaying it until we hit a ringer and some test finds something. So try as I might it seems that Im not ever getting the all clear. It could be worse, but I thought I was close to getting the see you in a year kind of thing. Now it seems Im back in the cycle. This is a frustrating problem! Prayers out for all those suffering.
Posts.Title: Continuing my saga

Posts.Content: 97% chance to live 10 years and 93% chance to live 15. Im presuming that means without treatment? Or is that with treatment? I always see cancer survivability rates but thats for breast, lung and pancreas where you have rates that are despite treatment. Does the 97% and 93% in my score include those who found it very late and will pass? Im confused by this. I know that even those who get rpa or radiation sometimes have additional pca show back up. So its just unclear whats included in these stats.
Posts.Title: New survival prediction tool

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by DjinTonic We have to take into account two facts in looking at risk figures. Not all men live long lives. For elderly guys, the older we get the greater the chances that we will die in x years from all non-PCa causes. The fact that we die from a non-PCa causes doesn't mean we don't have metastatic disease that is being treated and has serious symptoms. Risk calculators can lead you down the garden path: we are not all one "average". Aren't you better off trying to avoid bad or worst cases? I will need to deep dive the results and read, I just looked at the stats and remembered my question about survival rates. If they included other mortalities in there these results kind of become pointless. No matter what they find on my next or subsequent biopsies I still expect fully to die at the hands of my wife of 27 years. In fact Im really impressed with her restraint thus far! ðŸ˜€

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Duck2 Within 36 hours, a tumor the size of a golf ball on her forehead had disappeared, and within two weeks there was no cancer detectable in her body. Is this even biologically possible? I cant get rid of poison ivy in 36 hours. Good question. Maybe find someone with a bad case of measles and kiss them a few times next time you have poison ivy and report back? ðŸ˜€ If I had to guess being the newly coronated medical professional that I am thanks to this pca scare..... Im thinking that it might have been the bodys reaction to a great big giant dose of the measles. The article made it sound like she had some instant and palpable reactions with the headache, etc. Maybe the body recognized the super dose of measles as being so severe that the body had to send all of its infection fighting soldiers out to fight and then the cancer just got caught in the crossfire. Id be concerned with a few questions: 1). What if the bodys response also attacks healthy cells? 2). What if youre one of those people who cant fight off the measles so you die cancer free from the measles? 3). Its clear the tumor disappeared and wasnt THERE (as in where it was) any longer but did it dissolve the tumor into 10,000,000 individual cells of cancer that are landing in the lungs, brain and pancreas? It definitely has promise.

Posts.Title: I'm back ... ! Prostate surgery completed.

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by DjinTonic Ask your doc "You are giving me a nerve block before taking the cores, right???" Speaking as one with many biopsies under his belt (or lower), I can tell you (1) the doc's ability to do a good nerve block makes a huge difference, and (2) as the number of cores taken increases, the accumulative insult to the prostate build ups, and the closer the needle comes to the nerve plexus (the cores start from the apex, farthest from the plexus). This bottom (ha ha) line is that the biopsy becomes more uncomfortable as it goes on: speed is your friend Perhaps you can also ask you doc if he does an isopropy alcohol (or some other) wash of the needle between cores: this cuts down on infection complications and will make you look very well-informed too. I just scheduled my Sept biopsy and am going through the same dance trying to get it sedated because Valium doesnt affect me. They called back with insurance doesnt cover sedation and the only thing they offer for the procedure is Valium. Sigh. I finally got someone who cared and told them that if they called in and asked for sedation, it would likely be approved especially since Valium doesnt work. I had shoulder surgery once and they gave me something called Versed while I was waitingnot sure whybut I dont remember anything from that point on despite having conversations with anesthesiologists and others. I think this is lust laziness on their part. I know I cannot go through the procedure completely lucid again. So re the alcohol question I am trying to avoid asking any more questions and being more of a pain than I am. Im not saying that the doc might use too little numbing medication in retaliation but I dont want that thought to occur to him either ! ðŸ˜€

Posts.Content: Hang in there bud it looks like youre cruising towards a possible diagnosis but it could also be something as simple as prostatitis. For the appt I would expect to get felt up but it looks like youve already been felt up. You will likely get bloodwork and maybe even an ultrasound. They might give you a course of antibiotics and retest in a few weeks but with your symptoms they might go straight to a biopsy. This will make others laugh (Im the resident board worrier) but just relax nothing you can do about the outcome. Pca likely will not kill you but is just something you need to manage and deal with...a life inconvenience. For what its worth all my DRE were normal with no lumps or abnormalities found. My tests (all kinds) were a mixed bag with some pointing to cancer and others pointing away. The MRI was essentially useless since it pointed out a pirads 3/4 that wasnt cancer and missed a spot of cancer that they found via a random 12 core. So expect a lot of tests that honestly mean little to nothing unless they lead to a biopsy that finds cancer. Beyond that there is precious little certainty. Its definitely a marathon and not a dash, so this isnt something you can hit with a course of antibiotics and go in with life (unless its prostatitis). Either way..cancer or not...itll be something youre dealing with for a while. Best of luck! Prayers for a good outcome.

Posts.Title: Does curcumin reduce inflammation?

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by DjinTonic One of the huge advantages of AS is that a good portion of men with low-risk PCa will never need treatment. True, the other portion will need or opt for treatment down the pike, but that's the beauty of AS: treatment only for those who need it. The whole debate about PSA screening came about because of overtreatment. Today we know that many men should be on AS. What scares me about AS, after learning the shortcomings of all detection methods, is how do you know anything for certain? MRI cant tell you for certain that it detected all cancers. MRI cant accurately guarantee how big an area detected really is. MRI cant tell you for certain where the boundaries are. And MRI is the best detection method from an imaging perspective. So you do a biopsyrandom 12 core or focused fusion biopsyand find cancer. How do you know that the biopsy needle didnt hit a sample of low risk cancer thats right next to a sample of high risk that wasnt detected? Youre doing AS on a section while the undetected cancer spreads. I guess if I knew for certain that the MRI results were accurate and the spot of cancer wasnt growing, Id absolutely let it sit there and hurt nothing. For those doing AS how does your doc manage that risk of non-detection? ETA: Im not challenging anyones decision for or against AS but clearly I cant be the first person to think of these questions so they must have sufficiently been addressed by someone/somewhere.

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by ASAdvocate ISZ, It's a probability scheme, with a combination of PHI tests, DRE's, TRUS biopsies, 3T mp-MRIs, fusion biopsies, OncotypeDX and other genomics tests. When you do a regular schedule of all of those, you greatly reduce the odds of any significant cancer being missed. It takes much more than one biopsy to know what you are dealing with. A strict AS program gives you all the other testing. In Johns Hopkins' experience, there has been no additional mortality risk for men who began AS and later need treatment, versus those who chose immediate treatment. Yeah, see I edited above to say someone had to have thought about the questions I had above and they have. Thank you greatly for the information. Just when I think I understand it, I learn something new. I really appreciate the information. Im so young if my 2/13 biopsy comes back cancerous, Im going to have a hard time figuring out what to do. I have a lot of life to live with the symptoms of treatment. So if circumstances permit AS might work while I hope to kick the can down the road while technology catches up and advances.

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by KarlEmagne Seriously, numbers are sh*t. Just looked it up, PSA velocity > 2 in year pre op very significantly raises the risk of dying from PCa. 15% chance this will finish me off in 10 years. Oops. Wouldn't have thought it was this bad but explains why I got my biopsy appointment so quickly. On the upside, I'm a lot less worried about retirement savings lately. Dont write yourself off just yet. Or spend those retirement funds. A PSA velocity of >.5 or .6 in a year is suggestive of cancer but not a guarantee. Your 2 figure might be a guide but Im sure someone will be along with a study that says the alternative. There are a lot of non cancer explanations for your whacky numbers including prostatitis. I know there are no givens in this but with those huge jumps and the presumption that it was caused by cancer why would it suddenly drop? Sex didnt cause that big of a drop. I know this might sound funny from panic man (its my super power) but lets see what the biopsy shows. Any chance you can get the MRI first so that they can target anything it finds and THEN do a random 12 core? Hang in there buddy prayers out your way.
Posts.Title: Impact of sexual activity on PSA

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by dmwierz45 Just had my 6 week post-RALP uPSA and office visit with my Uro. My wife and I initially ran into my doctor in the waiting room, and he greeted us very straight-faced. Uh oh. 15 minutes later he walks into the exam room with a big smile on his face, reaches out and grasps my hand very firmly, and asks "have you seen your prostate number?". I replied "No". He says "Well, it's good news: your uPSA is 0.01" Phew... So, due to a number poor-risk factors, I'm now in the "uPSA every 6 weeks, with follow-up" until 6 months post op. My Uro says it's still possible I'll be looking at radiotherapy after I've had a chance to heal from my RALP, due to the high risk, aggressive nature of my cancer, and my poor risk factors, but all things considered, we're cautiously positive. Sure could've been a lot worse news. We're still awaiting the Decipher results, which were ordered a week after my RALP. Will review these, along with my next uPSA test, in March. Prayers brother, you have lots of them from me. Best of luck and I hope those numbers hold strong and you dont need radiation.

My wife and I initially ran into my doctor in the waiting room, and he greeted us very straight-faced. Uh oh. 15 minutes later he walks into the exam room with a big smile on his face, reaches out and grasps my hand very firmly, and asks "have you seen your prostate number?". I replied "No". He says "Well, it's good news: your uPSA is 0.01" Phew... So, due to a number poor-risk factors, I'm now in the "uPSA every 6 weeks, with follow-up" until 6 months post op. My Uro says it's still possible I'll be looking at radiotherapy after I've had a chance to heal from my RALP, due to the high risk, aggressive nature of my cancer, and my poor risk factors, but all things considered, we're cautiously positive. Sure could've been a lot worse news. We're still awaiting the Decipher results, which were ordered a week after my RALP. Will review these, along with my next uPSA test, in March. Prayers brother, you have lots of them from me. Best of luck and I hope those numbers hold strong and you dont need radiation.
Posts.Title: 6 week post-RALP uPSA: good news

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Another If unchecked, your thoughts will tempt you to go south. True that, the mind is a powerful drug. Its taken me back and forth from good grief theres nothing wrong to get your affairs in order. I think mine is just my age and stage in life, I have to be around for many years to grow my kids and secure their future. I keep coming back to come what may this will not likely kill me.
Posts.Title: Impact of sexual activity on PSA

Posts.Content: Im just simply impressed that you can remember that far back and how long it had been since sex. That got me thinking... Wedding night to first child conception...1,825 days First child to second...1,900 days ðŸ˜€ I guess youd also need to ensure there wasnt some infection related cause as well mixed in with the results. I wonder if theres any empirical evidence anywhere that backs up your experience.
Posts.Title: Impact of sexual activity on PSA

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by KarlEmagne Seriously, numbers are sh*t. Just looked it up, PSA velocity > 2 in year pre op very significantly raises the risk of dying from PCa. 15% chance this will finish me off in 10 years. Oops. Wouldn't have thought it was this bad but explains why I got my biopsy appointment so quickly. On the upside, I'm a lot less worried about retirement savings lately. Dont write yourself off just yet. Or spend those retirement funds. A PSA velocity of >.5 or .6 in a year is suggestive of cancer but not a guarantee. Your 2 figure might be a guide but Im sure someone will be along with a study that says the alternative. There are a lot of non cancer explanations for your whacky numbers including prostatitis. I know there are no givens in this but with those huge jumps and the presumption that it was caused by cancer why would it suddenly drop? Sex didnt cause that big of a drop. I know this might sound funny from panic man (its my super power) but lets see what the biopsy shows. Any chance you can get the MRI first so that they can target anything it finds and THEN do a random 12 core? Hang in there buddy prayers out your way.

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by KarlEmagne I had an MRI done in May 2018 that was inconclusive, no suspicious nodules visible, but a larger area that could be infection or cancer. The radiologist concluded I thus don't need a fusion biopsy, as they would likely hit this larger something. Though I live in a lager city, the biopsy is done at a small hospital not doing MRIs. In fact, when I asked around in March 2018, they were unpacking the MRI machine at the best university hospital in town and were just starting to do fusion biopsies. You are definitely right I should stop the head spinning, as it doesn't get me anywhere. Looking at this calculator, chances are good I might live another 10 years and chances are bad I'll be progression free. That, however, would have been almost the same back in March 2018. If I get a high Gleason score from my biopsy, then reading through other threads, most recommend seeking advice at one of the big hospital centers, for RP outcomes but also quality and variety of subsequent treatments. Just for the RP I'm not entirely sure this would pay off, but for newer other treatments options in my province are lagging behind. Since a 4-6 week wait for RP after biopsy is common, I'm still tempted to reactivate my 5 star private European health insurance starting from April. Even if the costs are high, this money might be well spent. Similar. Ive confirmed that the original random biopsy alread hit the area that raised questions with the pirads 3/4. That original biopsy mentioned inflammation, prostatitis and something else that makes no difference (benign). So Im hoping the mri report that said this looked like inflammation, prostatitis verses cancer is correct. But that leaves the nagging question of well great but what now?. Time will tell. As for you man, chillax. You have this. At this point you havent even had a positive biopsy result so all of this becomes mental torture. Imagine them coming back and saying nothing found then all the what if planning was just wasted effort. If it comes back cancer then its likely to be some scenario that you hadnt even planned contingencies for. Im the worst at trying to contingency plan so Im talking to myself as much as you. That need to know is nearly all consuming at times.

Posts.Content: This is one of the primary drivers of my leaning towards RP instead of Radiation if I need treatmentbecause as soon as I can get back on external testosterone the better...provided it is safe to do so.
Posts.Title: Comments on recent press release

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by RobLee "External testosterone", Iceman? What's the hurry? Have you been on HT? Hi yes I was on external testosterone replacement (androgel) for 10+ years. I had to stop a year ago because my PSA finally exceeded the 80+ year old levels and my PCP woke up and realized that I had a potential problem.. We tried stopping cold turkey and letting my body recover but it only got my total T back up to 267 or 270 I cant remember. Im a big strong strapping guy and I couldnt even mow my front yard with a walk behind (20 minute job) without stopping 3-4 times...it was like trying to mow the grass with raging flu. Since that didnt work and I was figuratively dying from lack of T (no mental sharpness, no drive at work, completely overwhelmed by simple mental tasks, weight gain, muscle loss and Ed)....my doctor went off label and is using clomid to naturally increase my own testosterone production. According to the numbers Im back up but I cant tell any difference in how I feel. Men were made to use testosterone and I need some badly. Plus theres the added risk of heart disease and diabetes that associates with extended periods of low t. Yes, Another, I know I need to lose weight and am working on it but I dont think that I would have enough t if I lost 100lbs. Im too tired to walk after work all I have the energy to do is fall asleep. Its not a want to problem, I want to walk and exercise but just dont have the energy. Again, go get the flu and try walking 3-4 miles after work. Ive legitimately tried enough times with the wife having to get in the car and come get me, so I just stopped.

AgeInfo.Phrase: my PSA finally exceeded the 80  year old levels and my

Posts.Title: Comments on recent press release

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by HighlanderCFH Ice, Johns Hopkins did a study years ago about their prostatectomy patients who were TRUE Gleason 6 patients -- meaning that the pathology report confirmed the biopsy report of only Gleason 6 and no higher grades found. Their study included 17,000 Gleason 6 patients. And out of those 17,000, the number of patients who had metastasized Gleason 6 was -- ABSOLUTE ZERO! As Djin noted, Gleason 6 CANNOT spread because it is not "sophisticated" enough to survive outside of the prostate. I can understand the sting you are feeling regarding the false diagnosis. The same thing happened to me..... I had pre-arranged for the uro's office to call me with my biopsy results, which came in a few days after the biopsy. When I got home, the first thing I did was check my Caller ID unit -- and I saw that the doctor's office had called me. So I went to my desk and very nervously sat down and picked up the phone to return their call. I remember thinking that the next minute or so could possibly define the rest of my life. I made the call and a woman answered and I told them who I was. She confirmed that the results of my biopsy were in and I heard her thumbing through the papers and finally pronounced, "I have it right here -- and it's BENIGN!" I cannot describe the profound relief I felt at that moment and said "Thank God" to myself as the relief poured through me. Then, it happened..... As I was sinking back in my chair with relief, she said, "Oh, wait a minute. I was reading someone else's report, hang on for a second." I heard her rifling through more papers and she came back on and said, "I just found your report -- and it is ... MALIGNANT!" Again, I cannot describe the head-on collision between my original sense of relief and the cold terror that suddenly began surging inside of me. I was really out of it for a few seconds as I tried to process what had just happened. This was on a Friday afternoon and she told me she could get me in to see the doctor in a week for all the details. Then she told me, "but you probably want to see him sooner than a week." And I almost answered, "NO SHIT?" So she said they would squeeze me in late the following Monday afternoon. So I had to spend the entire weekend with my mind dwelling on all the possibilities -- am I going to survive or should I avoid buying any green bananas? I had to fight down feelings of panic over & over. I wish I had known about this forum at that time, that's for sure. Fortunately, Monday arrived and I was as nervous as a snowball approaching Hell when my name was called to go into the exam room. The doctor was VERY gentle and nice and explained that I had 3 positive cores of Gleason 6 and that I would live out my full lifespan if I had surgery. With a prostate of almost 100 gms, and the BPH urination problems that went with it, I ended up having the surgery to cure both the cancer and the urination problems. That was over 7 years ago and my PSA remains zero and my urination remains at firehose levels. So, hang in there, my friend. Sometimes things that start off with horror end up being very good. And, with just one positive core -- of Gleason 6 -- you are going to be just fine! Thanks my friend. I appreciate the time you put into this post. You guys have definitely encouraged me. I awoke this AM in a pretty good mood. I was pretty aggravated early evening but finally got over it...spiked the plans to do tax work (I have a tax business) and ordered a pizza and Dr. Pepper and watched a movie. I think it was good that my wife was out of town because it freed me from trying to comfort her and let me come to terms with it. Yeah I know this is their jobs and people make mistakes but for crying out loud read the correct report and read it accurately. What if the opposite had happened and the misreported it as cancer and the person killed themselves out of grief only to get the correcting call too late? Im going to have to give the docs a pass, theyre only human but they definite get a great big ESPN cmon mannnnn. It was funny after all the trouble we had with the biopsy scheduling I think it was my wife who said I hope those were your results ðŸ˜€ I have a lot going on specifically I worry that the job I have now and associated insurance will last until said treatment is needed. A change in jobs or coverage quality could impact everything from how much I pay to the doctors I can see. Oh well, cest la vie, those taxes I spiked last night are calling. Thanks again, I really appreciate the encouragement.
Posts.Title: Im speechless....not sure how to even process this

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by DjinTonic Yes, G6 cannot metastasize, and repeat imaging/biopsies are part of the "active" in active surveillance I'm not sure why your doc is predicting early treatment. Perhaps it has to do with your other cores and a prediction based on his experience that your prostate will in the coming years generate a bit too much G6 to remain in AS. The concern with a prostate having many pattern 3 lesions is not these G6 lesions themselves, but rather that there is some pattern 4 hidden somewhere, i.e., G7 (3+4) or (4+3) lesions. Treatment at that point is aimed at preventing more serious cancer down the road. In fact, some of these men who have had only G6 biopies, reveal G7 lesions when their entire prostate is examined after surgery (remember a biopsy samples only about 1% of prostate tissue). In any case, treatment in AS men is highly successful: very few of these men die from the cancer. The Subforum here (near the top of the main Forum page) has an entire topic with papers on AS studies. You can take the next few years to relax and read about the success rates. Thanks again. Im pretty resolved at this point it it what it is. My doc said that 60% of people with scores like mine end up never needing treatment and 40% do. However he said that my age was the determining factor that I would not make it out of this life without needing treatment. Who knows what else he used for that opinion. I cant be certain he was looking at my records ðŸ˜€ Ill talk to them more soon. I guess through a combination of things they can monitor bia the AS but the paranoia of whats there and undiscovered is nagging at me. I cant decide if the cancer is the worse news or the fact that Ill need another biopsy in six months. Dear sweet fancy Moses.
Posts.Title: Im speechless....not sure how to even process this

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Littleman Thanks so much for your quick responses. I have posted here before when my husband 's PSA fluctuated from 3.4, down to .77 and finally up to 7.1. After reading the wealth of information on this forum, I asked his urologist for him to have an MRI (he suggested an in-office biopsy). I was so glad I did. The initial MRI report indicated that the "findings were suggestive of prostatitis". We breathed a sigh of relief until I read today's biopsy report. My husband is approaching 74 and is a survivor of a very aggressive form of leukemia, including a bone marrow transplant 5 years ago. When his PSA started fluctuating, the doctor quickly said that he would not be a candidate for surgery, primarily due to his age. I will report back as to what the urologist says. We live in New Jersey and are seen by doctors at The Cancer Institute in New Brunswick, where he was treated for his leukemia. We are more that willing to travel elsewhere for a second opinion. If anyone has a referral, it would be greatly appreciated. I have learned so much from this forum. Thanks so much! So very sorry for your husbands diagnosis, my best and prayers to him. Those words suggestive of prostatitis sent a shiver down my spine. Im waiting an MRI targeted biopsy Valentines week and my MRI report said the same.

AgeInfo.Phrase: <Z> My husband is approaching 74 and is a survivor of

Posts.Title: Interpretation of biopsy report

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by DjinTonic If you need treatment in 30 years, that treatment will very likely be a distant cousin to today's. Well true. He didnt seem to think I could get that far down the road, he kept stating 2-3 years was his expectations. I remember that because I was wondering if my current job would hold out that long should I need surgery. The other thing he mentioned that didnt give me great comfort is that they really didnt have AS stats regarding success past 10 years. That whole ten year mortality stat thing. He didnt have much comfort that he felt AS that long would be a success. Im asking the Mrs. to pick up he pathology report on Monday while Im at work. I hope to know more then.
Posts.Title: Im speechless....not sure how to even process this

Posts.Content: If youll remember, I got the call last week that my fusion + 12 core random biopsy came back with no cancer. 14 cores, 12 completely clear and 2 were pre-cancerous. We all kind of did the victory dance. I just got a call from the doctor who did the biopsythat I spoke to last Friday to the dayand....its cancer. He didnt even remember talking to me and was like you talked with me? But he had no idea what changed and how. I dont have the path report but what I was told was that it was found in the same area as the pirads 3/4 (right peripheral) but wasnt one of the cores targeted with the MRI. Gleason 3+3 in 20% of that particular core so he quantified it as low risk worthy of surveillance but he also told me I didnt have cancer last week. Do you people see why Im cynical? ðŸ˜€. For the love of all thats good and holy how do you get the relative all clear one Friday and cancer the next? Ive asked it to be sent to Johns Hopkins for a second opinion. And thats where I stand. I guess the sting for me was last week with the precancerous finding and I knew that meant the next biopsy would be cancerous most likely. So this news is more wth? Due to the snafu. The bad thing is that my son is away at college and my wife and daughter are out of town at a band program (my baby made all state) so Im completely alone this weekend and cant even tell my wife. It would wreck her trip and neither she nor my daughter would enjoy the rest of the weekend and this is a big weekend for both of them. 48 years old with prostate cancer. Wow.

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by DjinTonic ISZ, I know you were let down, but putting their screwup aside, you really do want to know what's going on in your prostate. You'll be in an AS program, and could well be in the large group of G6 (3+3) men who never need treatment. Make sure you get a written copy of you path report. My guess regarding your earlier all-clear call is that either records/patients got screwed up (less likely), or a regular review of you slides was done and your pathology revised (perhaps more probable). And yes, the JH path review is certainly warranted. Try to put this in perspective: one core with some G6 (3+3) is the absolute minimum you can have and still qualify to call it cancer. It can't metastasize, and you'll be monitored. IF anything of concern hapens in your future, you can be confident you've caught it as early as possible And you're not alone---we're all right here! Djin Thanks Djin. Im not there with you yet...but this is like two hours old. Its amazing the mind screw that happens when you hear the news for sure, its almost like youre starting over. I guess I was unaware that the 6 could not metastasize are you certain of that? So basically youre saying that piece cannot grow or spread to bones, etc.? The real rub is that we dont know what was missed. I could still have an aggressive cancer somewhere else..heck this was found in a random area. I dont know how AS is any more (or less) reliable than anything else in this adventure. My doc told me he would do another 12 core random in 6 months and an MRI again six months after that followed by a fusion biopsy. However his outlook wasnt so rosy. He said that the chances were great that this would progress and I would need treatment in the intermediate term of 3-5 years. So I am confused.
Posts.Title: Im speechless....not sure how to even process this

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by DjinTonic Yes, G6 cannot metastasize, and repeat imaging/biopsies are part of the "active" in active surveillance I'm not sure why your doc is predicting early treatment. Perhaps it has to do with your other cores and a prediction based on his experience that your prostate will in the coming years generate a bit too much G6 to remain in AS. The concern with a prostate having many pattern 3 lesions is not these G6 lesions themselves, but rather that there is some pattern 4 hidden somewhere, i.e., G7 (3+4) or (4+3) lesions. Treatment at that point is aimed at preventing more serious cancer down the road. In fact, some of these men who have had only G6 biopies, reveal G7 lesions when their entire prostate is examined after surgery (remember a biopsy samples only about 1% of prostate tissue). In any case, treatment in AS men is highly successful: very few of these men die from the cancer. The Subforum here (near the top of the main Forum page) has an entire topic with papers on AS studies. You can take the next few years to relax and read about the success rates. Thanks again. Im pretty resolved at this point it it what it is. My doc said that 60% of people with scores like mine end up never needing treatment and 40% do. However he said that my age was the determining factor that I would not make it out of this life without needing treatment. Who knows what else he used for that opinion. I cant be certain he was looking at my records ðŸ˜€ Ill talk to them more soon. I guess through a combination of things they can monitor bia the AS but the paranoia of whats there and undiscovered is nagging at me. I cant decide if the cancer is the worse news or the fact that Ill need another biopsy in six months. Dear sweet fancy Moses.

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by DjinTonic If you need treatment in 30 years, that treatment will very likely be a distant cousin to today's. Well true. He didnt seem to think I could get that far down the road, he kept stating 2-3 years was his expectations. I remember that because I was wondering if my current job would hold out that long should I need surgery. The other thing he mentioned that didnt give me great comfort is that they really didnt have AS stats regarding success past 10 years. That whole ten year mortality stat thing. He didnt have much comfort that he felt AS that long would be a success. Im asking the Mrs. to pick up he pathology report on Monday while Im at work. I hope to know more then.

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by HighlanderCFH Ice, Johns Hopkins did a study years ago about their prostatectomy patients who were TRUE Gleason 6 patients -- meaning that the pathology report confirmed the biopsy report of only Gleason 6 and no higher grades found. Their study included 17,000 Gleason 6 patients. And out of those 17,000, the number of patients who had metastasized Gleason 6 was -- ABSOLUTE ZERO! As Djin noted, Gleason 6 CANNOT spread because it is not "sophisticated" enough to survive outside of the prostate. I can understand the sting you are feeling regarding the false diagnosis. The same thing happened to me..... I had pre-arranged for the uro's office to call me with my biopsy results, which came in a few days after the biopsy. When I got home, the first thing I did was check my Caller ID unit -- and I saw that the doctor's office had called me. So I went to my desk and very nervously sat down and picked up the phone to return their call. I remember thinking that the next minute or so could possibly define the rest of my life. I made the call and a woman answered and I told them who I was. She confirmed that the results of my biopsy were in and I heard her thumbing through the papers and finally pronounced, "I have it right here -- and it's BENIGN!" I cannot describe the profound relief I felt at that moment and said "Thank God" to myself as the relief poured through me. Then, it happened..... As I was sinking back in my chair with relief, she said, "Oh, wait a minute. I was reading someone else's report, hang on for a second." I heard her rifling through more papers and she came back on and said, "I just found your report -- and it is ... MALIGNANT!" Again, I cannot describe the head-on collision between my original sense of relief and the cold terror that suddenly began surging inside of me. I was really out of it for a few seconds as I tried to process what had just happened. This was on a Friday afternoon and she told me she could get me in to see the doctor in a week for all the details. Then she told me, "but you probably want to see him sooner than a week." And I almost answered, "NO SHIT?" So she said they would squeeze me in late the following Monday afternoon. So I had to spend the entire weekend with my mind dwelling on all the possibilities -- am I going to survive or should I avoid buying any green bananas? I had to fight down feelings of panic over & over. I wish I had known about this forum at that time, that's for sure. Fortunately, Monday arrived and I was as nervous as a snowball approaching Hell when my name was called to go into the exam room. The doctor was VERY gentle and nice and explained that I had 3 positive cores of Gleason 6 and that I would live out my full lifespan if I had surgery. With a prostate of almost 100 gms, and the BPH urination problems that went with it, I ended up having the surgery to cure both the cancer and the urination problems. That was over 7 years ago and my PSA remains zero and my urination remains at firehose levels. So, hang in there, my friend. Sometimes things that start off with horror end up being very good. And, with just one positive core -- of Gleason 6 -- you are going to be just fine! Thanks my friend. I appreciate the time you put into this post. You guys have definitely encouraged me. I awoke this AM in a pretty good mood. I was pretty aggravated early evening but finally got over it...spiked the plans to do tax work (I have a tax business) and ordered a pizza and Dr. Pepper and watched a movie. I think it was good that my wife was out of town because it freed me from trying to comfort her and let me come to terms with it. Yeah I know this is their jobs and people make mistakes but for crying out loud read the correct report and read it accurately. What if the opposite had happened and the misreported it as cancer and the person killed themselves out of grief only to get the correcting call too late? Im going to have to give the docs a pass, theyre only human but they definite get a great big ESPN cmon mannnnn. It was funny after all the trouble we had with the biopsy scheduling I think it was my wife who said I hope those were your results ðŸ˜€ I have a lot going on specifically I worry that the job I have now and associated insurance will last until said treatment is needed. A change in jobs or coverage quality could impact everything from how much I pay to the doctors I can see. Oh well, cest la vie, those taxes I spiked last night are calling. Thanks again, I really appreciate the encouragement.
Posts.Title: Im speechless....not sure how to even process this

Posts.Content: If youll remember, I got the call last week that my fusion + 12 core random biopsy came back with no cancer. 14 cores, 12 completely clear and 2 were pre-cancerous. We all kind of did the victory dance. I just got a call from the doctor who did the biopsythat I spoke to last Friday to the dayand....its cancer. He didnt even remember talking to me and was like you talked with me? But he had no idea what changed and how. I dont have the path report but what I was told was that it was found in the same area as the pirads 3/4 (right peripheral) but wasnt one of the cores targeted with the MRI. Gleason 3+3 in 20% of that particular core so he quantified it as low risk worthy of surveillance but he also told me I didnt have cancer last week. Do you people see why Im cynical? ðŸ˜€. For the love of all thats good and holy how do you get the relative all clear one Friday and cancer the next? Ive asked it to be sent to Johns Hopkins for a second opinion. And thats where I stand. I guess the sting for me was last week with the precancerous finding and I knew that meant the next biopsy would be cancerous most likely. So this news is more wth? Due to the snafu. The bad thing is that my son is away at college and my wife and daughter are out of town at a band program (my baby made all state) so Im completely alone this weekend and cant even tell my wife. It would wreck her trip and neither she nor my daughter would enjoy the rest of the weekend and this is a big weekend for both of them. 48 years old with prostate cancer. Wow.

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Littleman Thanks so much for your quick responses. I have posted here before when my husband 's PSA fluctuated from 3.4, down to .77 and finally up to 7.1. After reading the wealth of information on this forum, I asked his urologist for him to have an MRI (he suggested an in-office biopsy). I was so glad I did. The initial MRI report indicated that the "findings were suggestive of prostatitis". We breathed a sigh of relief until I read today's biopsy report. My husband is approaching 74 and is a survivor of a very aggressive form of leukemia, including a bone marrow transplant 5 years ago. When his PSA started fluctuating, the doctor quickly said that he would not be a candidate for surgery, primarily due to his age. I will report back as to what the urologist says. We live in New Jersey and are seen by doctors at The Cancer Institute in New Brunswick, where he was treated for his leukemia. We are more that willing to travel elsewhere for a second opinion. If anyone has a referral, it would be greatly appreciated. I have learned so much from this forum. Thanks so much! So very sorry for your husbands diagnosis, my best and prayers to him. Those words suggestive of prostatitis sent a shiver down my spine. Im waiting an MRI targeted biopsy Valentines week and my MRI report said the same.

Perhaps it has to do with your other cores and a prediction based on his experience that your prostate will in the coming years generate a bit too much G6 to remain in AS. The concern with a prostate having many pattern 3 lesions is not these G6 lesions themselves, but rather that there is some pattern 4 hidden somewhere, i.e., G7 (3+4) or (4+3) lesions. Treatment at that point is aimed at preventing more serious cancer down the road. In fact, some of these men who have had only G6 biopies, reveal G7 lesions when their entire prostate is examined after surgery (remember a biopsy samples only about 1% of prostate tissue). In any case, treatment in AS men is highly successful: very few of these men die from the cancer. The Subforum here (near the top of the main Forum page) has an entire topic with papers on AS studies. You can take the next few years to relax and read about the success rates. Thanks again. Posts.Content: Originally Posted by DjinTonic Yes, G6 cannot metastasize, and repeat imaging/biopsies are part of the "active" in active surveillance I'm not sure why your doc is predicting early treatment. Perhaps it has to do with your other cores and a prediction based on his experience that your prostate will in the coming years generate a bit too much G6 to remain in AS. The concern with a prostate having many pattern 3 lesions is not these G6 lesions themselves, but rather that there is some pattern 4 hidden somewhere, i.e., G7 (3+4) or (4+3) lesions. Treatment at that point is aimed at preventing more serious cancer down the road. In fact, some of these men who have had only G6 biopies, reveal G7 lesions when their entire prostate is examined after surgery (remember a biopsy samples only about 1% of prostate tissue). In any case, treatment in AS men is highly successful: very few of these men die from the cancer. The Subforum here (near the top of the main Forum page) has an entire topic with papers on AS studies. You can take the next few years to relax and read about the success rates. Thanks again. Im pretty resolved at this point it it what it is. My doc said that 60% of people with scores like mine end up never needing treatment and 40% do. However he said that my age was the determining factor that I would not make it out of this life without needing treatment. Who knows what else he used for that opinion. I cant be certain he was looking at my records ðŸ˜€ Ill talk to them more soon. I guess through a combination of things they can monitor bia the AS but the paranoia of whats there and undiscovered is nagging at me. I cant decide if the cancer is the worse news or the fact that Ill need another biopsy in six months. Dear sweet fancy Moses.
Posts.Title: Im speechless....not sure how to even process this

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by HighlanderCFH Ice, Johns Hopkins did a study years ago about their prostatectomy patients who were TRUE Gleason 6 patients -- meaning that the pathology report confirmed the biopsy report of only Gleason 6 and no higher grades found. Their study included 17,000 Gleason 6 patients. And out of those 17,000, the number of patients who had metastasized Gleason 6 was -- ABSOLUTE ZERO! As Djin noted, Gleason 6 CANNOT spread because it is not "sophisticated" enough to survive outside of the prostate. I can understand the sting you are feeling regarding the false diagnosis. The same thing happened to me..... I had pre-arranged for the uro's office to call me with my biopsy results, which came in a few days after the biopsy. When I got home, the first thing I did was check my Caller ID unit -- and I saw that the doctor's office had called me. So I went to my desk and very nervously sat down and picked up the phone to return their call. I remember thinking that the next minute or so could possibly define the rest of my life. I made the call and a woman answered and I told them who I was. She confirmed that the results of my biopsy were in and I heard her thumbing through the papers and finally pronounced, "I have it right here -- and it's BENIGN!" I cannot describe the profound relief I felt at that moment and said "Thank God" to myself as the relief poured through me. Then, it happened..... As I was sinking back in my chair with relief, she said, "Oh, wait a minute. I was reading someone else's report, hang on for a second." I heard her rifling through more papers and she came back on and said, "I just found your report -- and it is ... MALIGNANT!" Again, I cannot describe the head-on collision between my original sense of relief and the cold terror that suddenly began surging inside of me. I was really out of it for a few seconds as I tried to process what had just happened. This was on a Friday afternoon and she told me she could get me in to see the doctor in a week for all the details. Then she told me, "but you probably want to see him sooner than a week." And I almost answered, "NO SHIT?" So she said they would squeeze me in late the following Monday afternoon. So I had to spend the entire weekend with my mind dwelling on all the possibilities -- am I going to survive or should I avoid buying any green bananas? I had to fight down feelings of panic over & over. I wish I had known about this forum at that time, that's for sure. Fortunately, Monday arrived and I was as nervous as a snowball approaching Hell when my name was called to go into the exam room. The doctor was VERY gentle and nice and explained that I had 3 positive cores of Gleason 6 and that I would live out my full lifespan if I had surgery. With a prostate of almost 100 gms, and the BPH urination problems that went with it, I ended up having the surgery to cure both the cancer and the urination problems. That was over 7 years ago and my PSA remains zero and my urination remains at firehose levels. So, hang in there, my friend. Sometimes things that start off with horror end up being very good. And, with just one positive core -- of Gleason 6 -- you are going to be just fine! Thanks my friend. I appreciate the time you put into this post. You guys have definitely encouraged me. I awoke this AM in a pretty good mood. I was pretty aggravated early evening but finally got over it...spiked the plans to do tax work (I have a tax business) and ordered a pizza and Dr. Pepper and watched a movie. I think it was good that my wife was out of town because it freed me from trying to comfort her and let me come to terms with it. Yeah I know this is their jobs and people make mistakes but for crying out loud read the correct report and read it accurately. What if the opposite had happened and the misreported it as cancer and the person killed themselves out of grief only to get the correcting call too late? Im going to have to give the docs a pass, theyre only human but they definite get a great big ESPN cmon mannnnn. It was funny after all the trouble we had with the biopsy scheduling I think it was my wife who said I hope those were your results ðŸ˜€ I have a lot going on specifically I worry that the job I have now and associated insurance will last until said treatment is needed. A change in jobs or coverage quality could impact everything from how much I pay to the doctors I can see. Oh well, cest la vie, those taxes I spiked last night are calling. Thanks again, I really appreciate the encouragement.
Posts.Title: Im speechless....not sure how to even process this

Posts.Content: Sounds like youre well ahead of the curve. Prayers for continued recovery!

I remember that because I was wondering if my current job would hold out that long should I need surgery. He didnt have much comfort that he felt AS that long would be a success. Im asking the Mrs. to pick up he pathology report on Monday while Im at work. I hope to know more then.

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by DjinTonic ISZ, I know you were let down, but putting their screwup aside, you really do want to know what's going on in your prostate. You'll be in an AS program, and could well be in the large group of G6 (3+3) men who never need treatment. Make sure you get a written copy of you path report. My guess regarding your earlier all-clear call is that either records/patients got screwed up (less likely), or a regular review of you slides was done and your pathology revised (perhaps more probable). And yes, the JH path review is certainly warranted. Try to put this in perspective: one core with some G6 (3+3) is the absolute minimum you can have and still qualify to call it cancer. It can't metastasize, and you'll be monitored. IF anything of concern hapens in your future, you can be confident you've caught it as early as possible And you're not alone---we're all right here! Djin Thanks Djin. Im not there with you yet...but this is like two hours old. Its amazing the mind screw that happens when you hear the news for sure, its almost like youre starting over. I guess I was unaware that the 6 could not metastasize are you certain of that? So basically youre saying that piece cannot grow or spread to bones, etc.? The real rub is that we dont know what was missed. I could still have an aggressive cancer somewhere else..heck this was found in a random area. I dont know how AS is any more (or less) reliable than anything else in this adventure. My doc told me he would do another 12 core random in 6 months and an MRI again six months after that followed by a fusion biopsy. However his outlook wasnt so rosy. He said that the chances were great that this would progress and I would need treatment in the intermediate term of 3-5 years. So I am confused.

Posts.Content: If youll remember, I got the call last week that my fusion + 12 core random biopsy came back with no cancer. 14 cores, 12 completely clear and 2 were pre-cancerous. We all kind of did the victory dance. I just got a call from the doctor who did the biopsythat I spoke to last Friday to the dayand....its cancer. He didnt even remember talking to me and was like you talked with me? But he had no idea what changed and how. I dont have the path report but what I was told was that it was found in the same area as the pirads 3/4 (right peripheral) but wasnt one of the cores targeted with the MRI. Gleason 3+3 in 20% of that particular core so he quantified it as low risk worthy of surveillance but he also told me I didnt have cancer last week. Do you people see why Im cynical? ðŸ˜€. For the love of all thats good and holy how do you get the relative all clear one Friday and cancer the next? Ive asked it to be sent to Johns Hopkins for a second opinion. And thats where I stand. I guess the sting for me was last week with the precancerous finding and I knew that meant the next biopsy would be cancerous most likely. So this news is more wth? Due to the snafu. The bad thing is that my son is away at college and my wife and daughter are out of town at a band program (my baby made all state) so Im completely alone this weekend and cant even tell my wife. It would wreck her trip and neither she nor my daughter would enjoy the rest of the weekend and this is a big weekend for both of them. 48 years old with prostate cancer. Wow.

Posts.Content: Okay besides the blood in the urine and the other stuff....Ive really had no problem from the biopsy on 2/13....except. Two days ago I had this knot form in the area where the two antibiotic shots were administered. I know it sounds crazy that nearly two weeks later it starts hurting but wasnt hurting immediately afterwards. Sometimes I get up and walk and it starts a really focused searing burning pain. Other times its just very sore if I roll over on it at night in the bed. Then other times I just very lightly run my hand over the skin and its very sensitivealmost like rubbing your hand over a wasp sting. Im not running a fever but this seems to be getting worse instead of better. Anyone else ever experienced this?

Posts.Title: quick update

Posts.Content: Just updating this thread ... its still there. Still hard and about the size of 1/2 of a small grade a egg youd buy at the store. Its definitely a part of the muscle and not between the muscle and skin. Im perplexed. No fever. It doesnt especially hurt in any way but I would THINK it should have gone away by now. Im hesitant given the hassle Ive been through with this doctor to contact them. Butt (see what I did there) ðŸ˜€this is really odd so I dont want it to be something that gets out of hand. So I contacted the doctor and will see what he says .
Posts.Title: Dont think that I am crazy

Posts.Content: Oh yeah, sorry one more thing..... I believe at some point the androgel stopped working or stopped being effective and my body started its own T production again. I stopped the androgel over 2 weeks ago and I feel better than ever. I'm anxious as can be about this chance of cancer but my sex life is better than it has been in forever (feel real desire again and morning erections). My mind is a little foggier but energy is fine. I have a STRONG belief that I was converting much of the androgel to estrogen. My urologist said on androgel stopping cold turkey, I should see any crash within a few days....but I feel fine. If this turns out to be BPH this might save me a lot of mess and money!

Posts.Title: Scared to death.....

Posts.Content: Hi all, I'm new here and terrified (have those words ever been uttered here? ). Trying desperately to keep some perspective, while I wait two more days for my biopsy results. I'm 47 years old and went on Androgel about, I don't know, 10-12 years ago because my T levels were 260 at age 37 or 38. Ummm worked okay I guess--super expensive and a pain to administer/deal with. Life bumped along until two weeks ago when I did some routine bloodwork and received a message from my primary care doc who had been measuring my PSA. It had bounced to 4.1 which exceeded the high end level. He apparently had been asleep at the wheel (I had no idea about PSA velocity or rising PSA), here are my PSA levels by year: 2012: 2.2 2013: 2.6 2014: 2.8 2015: 3.1 2016: 3.5 2017: ? I don't have a copy, I'm SURE we measured it. 2018: 4.1 He should have clued in something was wrong, so I referred to a urologist immediately and stopped the androgel. The doc said androgel probably wouldn't cause the high reading but might just accelerate the trajectory of where my prostate was going anyway. Family history: Dad aged 75 has the prostate of a 25 year old. Half brother, nothing. DRE showed a larger than average prostate (but I'm a big guy, 6'3" 295) that subsequently measured 46 ML on an ultrasound--large prostate, lots of PSA. The prostate was smooth, no nodules or bumps. On the ultrasound the doc said he saw no signs of odd density or oddities, nothing to worry about from the ultrasound. The doctor measured my free PSA that measured at 10% that gave me >50% chance of cancer until you discounted my age. The doc plugged my numbers into his handy dandy calculator and told me 75% chance it's BPH and 25% and chance it's cancer. He said his threshold to 'wait and see' was 20%, so being the worry wart I am I opted for the biopsy. No anesthesia but he gave me 30 mg of Xanax that kicked in about 30 minutes AFTER the biopsy was over, I hear I enjoyed the bagel my wife bought me on the way home (don't remember it). But I remember every SECOND of that barbaric biopsy. Anyway, that's it. The doctor said he believes it will ultimately be BPH but I'm just scared to death that it's cancer. The doctor said that even if it was cancer, it's 87% chance it's NOT the aggressive kill you type and that he'd get rid of it and the ride to the doctor's office would be riskier than the cancer...with regards to my life. I go Thursday (two days from now) to get the results and I'm having trouble eating and sleeping worrying about this. A wife and a college freshman and high school freshman, I have a lot of people who need me around.

Posts.Title: Scared to death.....

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Michael F Welcome ISZ! First & Foremost: Relax & Do NOT Panic! While we are not MDs and can not make predictions, I can assure you that all of us share the opinion that You will be around for a long time. Some points to consider: - You are young. Men in their 40's can/do get PCa but it is far more prevalent with men in their 60's. Thus the statistics are in your favor. - You prostate gland is large. The Ultrasound is not as accurate as an MRI in measuring prostate volume. So yours may actually be larger than 46 cc. - You PSA is definitely elevated and rising. However, the rate of rise is NOT meteoric which is good. - 10% Free PSA is concerning but in now way diagnostic of PCa - Your URO MD does not seem suspect PCa so neither should you! Did the URO MD not inject your prostate with lidocaine prior to biopsy? On the long list of Things No Man Has Ever Said is: "I really relaxed & enjoyed the time between walking into my Urologist's office to have my biopsy and returning a week later for the results!" Good luck and best wishes for walking out of the office next visit with all good results! Be sure to get a copy of the Path Report for your records. Keep us updated. MF Thanks for the reassurance. Consensus seems to be Im okay so Im holding you all to that! ðŸ˜€ He did inject it with lidocain and once he did, it was fine. In fact I told him to take extra samples if he wanted because I wanted to be sure. I felt one minor twinge on one of the samples. The problem was getting the thing in there. Not sure how others are but this thing was shaped like a longer, large Nintendo Wii controller. I first thought awesome, while waiting for the Xanax to kick in were going to play Wii golf. No were gonna play hide this giant brick sized ultrasound and knife attack machine in there. It was a bit of a struggle because theres just no way to relax during THAT! But I got through it and then stumbled around like a cast member of the walking dead at the bagel shop. I dont remember a thing about that experience but am in intensive therapy trying to forget the biopsy. ðŸ˜€ I think Im going to fire my primary care doc and write him a letter informing him why and what he should be doing for other patients on TRT. And technically for men not on TRT, if their velocity increases like mine. .5 is apparently a pretty reliabile indicator of high probability of cancer. The good news is that unless I crash, I plan to be off the TRT. Hated being dependent on that stuff and hoping that each insurer plan covers it.

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by HighlanderCFH Welcome aboard to BOTH of you. Ice, I believe your uro is probably correct that this is NOT a case of prostate cancer, but the result of a steadily growing prostate. Prostate tissue creates PSA and, of course, larger prostates produce more PSA. Normal PSA readings for the 40s age group is 0 - 2.5. You're approaching the age group of the 50s, for which the range is 0 - 3.5. So you're not horribly far from the high norm. In addition, your PSA elevation has been a slow, steady increase over the past few years, which kind of dovetails with your BPH. You'll probably be just fine -- but will be in a situation where I was at in that an enlarged prostate/higher PSA could someday be masking a tumor, which would probably be reflected by a rapid spike in the PSA reading. This means that you'll want to have regular PSA tests from now on to keep an eye on things. Good luck! Chuck Thanks Chuck, very helpful. You may be completely and totally wrong and I might have a raging case of PC, but your response will help me get through this nightmare. I alternate from I feel absolutely fine and have next to no symptoms to I cant breathe Im so scared. Little area in between.

Posts.Title: Three year checkup

Posts.Content: Hi all, Nervously awaiting my biopsy results and a question popped into my head that I dont think was ever asked. I know plenty of you have had negative original biopsies only to have a later positive biopsy. However, has anyone had the situation where the first biopsy result was totally clear and a later biopsy showed a surprising amount of cancer? My original biopsy was March of last year and was complete clear. Im wondering what to expect from these fusion results...I would expect that just a year later if there is any cancer at all it should be relatively localizedperhaps in the PIRADS 3/4 area. I would be a little surprised if the 12 core random biopsy samples they took after the fusion came back with significant cancer in degree or quantity. Basically my interpretation of the clean biopsy from last March was that it could only say that My prostate wasnt completely eaten up with cancer. Just curious if anyone had the surprise lots of cancer on a second biopsy. Am I making any sense what so ever?

Posts.Title: Question about biopsy changes

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by DjinTonic The laterality (uni- or bilateral), and also the extent to some degree, of cancer that is prostate-confined has little correlation with biochemical recurrence (the return of increasing PSA after primary treatment). The new edition of the TNM staging guide does away with subclassifying stage pT2 for that reason. The TMN 8th edition: Validation of the proposal for organ - confined (pT2) prostate cancer [2018] [Emphasis mine] Roughly 1/3 of (random) 12-core TRUS biopsies miss existing cancer. My final biopsy found cancer on one side only, yet it was present one both sides. Nontheless, the cancer involved only about 5% of my prostate. In other words, PCa is multifocal and can pop up all over, even if there is often a "primary" lesions which is the largest and perhaps the oldest. As I see it, what is more important that the number of lesions or total amount of tumor in a biopsy is: The Gleason score, which contributes significantly to the risk classification of the cancer Is the cancer prostate-confined or not? The cancer can spread either by growing out of the prostate capsule, by growing through the prostate base into neighboring anatomical structures or by sending off metastases, local or distant. The location of the lesions and imaging can give you a not-always-accurate idea as to whether the cancer is prostate-confined. The genomics (genetic nature) of the cancer--basically its aggressiveness and tendency to metastasize. This can be independent of the Gleason score. Based on a biopsy, there are really 3 outcomes: No cancer found (which does not mean it isn't there) Cancer that be monitored by active surveillance Cancer that needs to be treated If you have a 2nd negative biopsy, you should continue to be on your uro's radar to be followed diligently. The chance of missing existing cancer go down very fast with repeat biopsies. Thank you, very informative. I was hoping for a get outta here, that never happens but instinctively knew it had to...to someone, somewhere. Yesterday I hit a zen kind of peace about it and today Im having a hard time breathing due to the worry. Maybe I instinctively knew it couldnt possibly be delivered yesterday. I guess thats my next question for the doc if I get really blessed and the MRI fusion and the second random 12 core comes back clean....what next? I think weve just about done every test at this point.
Posts.Title: Question about biopsy changes

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by RobLee Yes my initial biopsy was totally negative... no sign of cancer. The fusion biopsy two years later showed that 25% of my prostate was grade 4, Gleason 8. How did that happen? Without an MRI and a fusion biopsy, the urologist can only access less than one half of the prostate. In other words, my original urologist - in my opinion, didn't even look. It's like opening the closet door and saying nothing in here but clothes, without bothering to at least look around. By the time I was on my third urologist, I remarked on a graphic he had hanging in his office which showed that the top half of the prostate (the "base") is entirely hidden behind the pubic bone. I said "no wonder my other urologist couldn't find my cancer" and he said "yeah, you can never find them up there." So how could one's cancer progress from non-existent to very high risk and locally advanced in just two years? By a urologist who was not entirely honest with the patient. He made no attempt whatsoever to INFORM me of the possibility of a false negative biopsy. He only told me that my biopsy was negative and that my prostate was normal. In my mind, performing a biopsy that completely missed a sizable tumor should be grounds for a lawsuit. But of course that would likely be a futile effort and would just make me feel worse. And so because two years were lost, I am basically now an incontinent eunuch with major depressive disorder. I certainly hope you don't end up that way. I always assumed that a doctor would know what he's doing and that he would act only in the patient's best interest. Not so. Thank you for your reply. Im very sorry this happened to you. I wish I had some magic wand to make it all better for you but can only offer my prayers and artfully dealt sarcastic wit. The pirads 3/4 they identified is in the right peripheral lobe and should have been reachable, I think. My last biopsy showed inflammation and prostatitis and some other benign condition but I dont have the report to tell me where those samples hit. If they were in the right peripheral the 3/4 that showed up on the MRI might be what was found last time. Hang in there my friend.
Posts.Title: Question about biopsy changes

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by DjinTonic The best medicine now is to relax!! If it's cancer you will deal with it and be done. If it's not, your doc will look elsewhere for any symptoms you're having. It's possible that there are repeat biopsies in your future. Imaging, especially newer PET scans, are improving and are starting to be used for diagnosis. After my I-don't-remember-which-number negative biopsy, my doc said "We are not going to let you die of high-grade cancer."Turns out we subsequently did find very high-grade cancer. The good news is that he's kept his promise so far: I'm alive and typing. Glad to hear it....glad you made it brother. Thats the funny thing up until I got that Ill fated email from my pcp this time last year I never had the first symptom of any significance. So theres not much to treat. I do have some Ed but I think thats because they stopped the testosterone replacement and might be BPH related to some extent. But even thats manageable. Remember that 80s shirt Frankie says relax, well I used to say Frankie needs his butt whipped. Relaxing is not my thing...certainly not right now. But Ill try to as best I can.

Consensus seems to be Im okay so Im holding you all to that! ðŸ˜€ He did inject it with lidocain and once he did, it was fine. In fact I told him to take extra samples if he wanted because I wanted to be sure. I felt one minor twinge on one of the samples. The problem was getting the thing in there. Not sure how others are but this thing was shaped like a longer, large Nintendo Wii controller. I first thought awesome, while waiting for the Xanax to kick in were going to play Wii golf. No were gonna play hide this giant brick sized ultrasound and knife attack machine in there. It was a bit of a struggle because theres just no way to relax during THAT! But I got through it and then stumbled around like a cast member of the walking dead at the bagel shop. I dont remember a thing about that experience but am in intensive therapy trying to forget the biopsy. ðŸ˜€ I think Im going to fire my primary care doc and write him a letter informing him why and what he should be doing for other patients on TRT. And technically for men not on TRT, if their velocity increases like mine. .5 is apparently a pretty reliabile indicator of high probability of cancer. The good news is that unless I crash, I plan to be off the TRT. Hated being dependent on that stuff and hoping that each insurer plan covers it.

Posts.Content: Oh yeah, sorry one more thing..... I believe at some point the androgel stopped working or stopped being effective and my body started its own T production again. I stopped the androgel over 2 weeks ago and I feel better than ever. I'm anxious as can be about this chance of cancer but my sex life is better than it has been in forever (feel real desire again and morning erections). My mind is a little foggier but energy is fine. I have a STRONG belief that I was converting much of the androgel to estrogen. My urologist said on androgel stopping cold turkey, I should see any crash within a few days....but I feel fine. If this turns out to be BPH this might save me a lot of mess and money!

Posts.Title: Scared to death.....

Posts.Content: Hi all, I'm new here and terrified (have those words ever been uttered here? ). Trying desperately to keep some perspective, while I wait two more days for my biopsy results. I'm 47 years old and went on Androgel about, I don't know, 10-12 years ago because my T levels were 260 at age 37 or 38. Ummm worked okay I guess--super expensive and a pain to administer/deal with. Life bumped along until two weeks ago when I did some routine bloodwork and received a message from my primary care doc who had been measuring my PSA. It had bounced to 4.1 which exceeded the high end level. He apparently had been asleep at the wheel (I had no idea about PSA velocity or rising PSA), here are my PSA levels by year: 2012: 2.2 2013: 2.6 2014: 2.8 2015: 3.1 2016: 3.5 2017: ? I don't have a copy, I'm SURE we measured it. 2018: 4.1 He should have clued in something was wrong, so I referred to a urologist immediately and stopped the androgel. The doc said androgel probably wouldn't cause the high reading but might just accelerate the trajectory of where my prostate was going anyway. Family history: Dad aged 75 has the prostate of a 25 year old. Half brother, nothing. DRE showed a larger than average prostate (but I'm a big guy, 6'3" 295) that subsequently measured 46 ML on an ultrasound--large prostate, lots of PSA. The prostate was smooth, no nodules or bumps. On the ultrasound the doc said he saw no signs of odd density or oddities, nothing to worry about from the ultrasound. The doctor measured my free PSA that measured at 10% that gave me >50% chance of cancer until you discounted my age. The doc plugged my numbers into his handy dandy calculator and told me 75% chance it's BPH and 25% and chance it's cancer. He said his threshold to 'wait and see' was 20%, so being the worry wart I am I opted for the biopsy. No anesthesia but he gave me 30 mg of Xanax that kicked in about 30 minutes AFTER the biopsy was over, I hear I enjoyed the bagel my wife bought me on the way home (don't remember it). But I remember every SECOND of that barbaric biopsy. Anyway, that's it. The doctor said he believes it will ultimately be BPH but I'm just scared to death that it's cancer. The doctor said that even if it was cancer, it's 87% chance it's NOT the aggressive kill you type and that he'd get rid of it and the ride to the doctor's office would be riskier than the cancer...with regards to my life. I go Thursday (two days from now) to get the results and I'm having trouble eating and sleeping worrying about this. A wife and a college freshman and high school freshman, I have a lot of people who need me around.

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by HighlanderCFH You would be getting a radical prostatectomy -- which means the ENTIRE prostate and all associated glands (seminal vesicles, etc) would all come out. Unless they suspect a patient has a tumor in the prostate bed -- in the future, after surgery -- there would be no need of any further biopsies. Just PSA tests. In fact, digital rectal exams, themselves, usually become a thing of the past. And that is a real pleasure!! LOL We need one of those name brand drug commercials for RP. (Cue the patient testimonies). #1-Before my RP I was yanking my pants down faster and more than a hooker. Not any more! #2-my rectum was visited more than interstate 75 between Atlanta and Chattanooga. #3-i felt like someone left my name and number on a bathroom stall. Now its all quiet! (Cue the announcer voice) once youve had your RP you dont have to take your pants down and bend over for ANYONE. RP be finger and whiffle ball bat free!!! Im almost sold after that fusion biopsy! ðŸ˜€

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by DjinTonic In addition to cores taken in any areas the mpMRI identified as suspicious, a fusion biopsy usually includes the 12 cores taken randomly throughout the prostate. They aren't always exactly random, because the uro can sometimes see things that look suspicious in the ultrasound used to guide the biopsy needle. That is what mine did they apparently have an ultrasound machine so Advanced that it rivals identification of cancer as the MRI. My doc took a while with that whiffleball bat so Im hoping that his results were good and very thorough.

He should have never been allowed on stage to give a TED Talk related to being diagnosed with prostate cancer. He is on AS! He has not been affected by Prostate Cancer except for his self proclaimed grossly inappropriate psychological impacts of a disease status that is most likely 100% harmless to him. He received a gift diagnosis not a death sentence! He has not experienced any of the following either individually or in combination: Radiation Therapy, Radical Prostatectomy Surgery, Hormone Therapy; Radical Prostatectomy Surgery followed by Radiation Therapy, Any of these combined with Hormone Therapy, incontinence, erectile dysfunction, loss of masculinity during treatment and obviously not death by prostate cancer. No, he experienced no pain or suffering. He has never had to battle the disease. Rather he used his "misfortune" to snag a new girlfriend and ride off to a new start in his blue convertible. Get out the puke bags buddy!!! Instead Mr McCarthy stands in the spotlight and insipidly spews out a theme stolen from the great Al Greene: Love and Happiness. What a misguided total fool! What an insult to the members of this forum who have been truly impacted by prostate cancer. Sorry Mr SubDenis but you should remove the link to Mr McCarthy's shameful self-aggrandizing charade. Nevermind...
