Posts.Content: Originally Posted by DjinTonic The laterality (uni- or bilateral), and also the extent to some degree, of cancer that is prostate-confined has little correlation with biochemical recurrence (the return of increasing PSA after primary treatment). The new edition of the TNM staging guide does away with subclassifying stage pT2 for that reason. The TMN 8th edition: Validation of the proposal for organ - confined (pT2) prostate cancer [2018] [Emphasis mine] Roughly 1/3 of (random) 12-core TRUS biopsies miss existing cancer. My final biopsy found cancer on one side only, yet it was present one both sides. Nontheless, the cancer involved only about 5% of my prostate. In other words, PCa is multifocal and can pop up all over, even if there is often a "primary" lesions which is the largest and perhaps the oldest. As I see it, what is more important that the number of lesions or total amount of tumor in a biopsy is: The Gleason score, which contributes significantly to the risk classification of the cancer Is the cancer prostate-confined or not? The cancer can spread either by growing out of the prostate capsule, by growing through the prostate base into neighboring anatomical structures or by sending off metastases, local or distant. The location of the lesions and imaging can give you a not-always-accurate idea as to whether the cancer is prostate-confined. The genomics (genetic nature) of the cancer--basically its aggressiveness and tendency to metastasize. This can be independent of the Gleason score. Based on a biopsy, there are really 3 outcomes: No cancer found (which does not mean it isn't there) Cancer that be monitored by active surveillance Cancer that needs to be treated If you have a 2nd negative biopsy, you should continue to be on your uro's radar to be followed diligently. The chance of missing existing cancer go down very fast with repeat biopsies. Thank you, very informative. I was hoping for a get outta here, that never happens but instinctively knew it had to...to someone, somewhere. Yesterday I hit a zen kind of peace about it and today Im having a hard time breathing due to the worry. Maybe I instinctively knew it couldnt possibly be delivered yesterday. I guess thats my next question for the doc if I get really blessed and the MRI fusion and the second random 12 core comes back clean....what next? I think weve just about done every test at this point.
Posts.Title: Question about biopsy changes

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by RobLee Yes my initial biopsy was totally negative... no sign of cancer. The fusion biopsy two years later showed that 25% of my prostate was grade 4, Gleason 8. How did that happen? Without an MRI and a fusion biopsy, the urologist can only access less than one half of the prostate. In other words, my original urologist - in my opinion, didn't even look. It's like opening the closet door and saying nothing in here but clothes, without bothering to at least look around. By the time I was on my third urologist, I remarked on a graphic he had hanging in his office which showed that the top half of the prostate (the "base") is entirely hidden behind the pubic bone. I said "no wonder my other urologist couldn't find my cancer" and he said "yeah, you can never find them up there." So how could one's cancer progress from non-existent to very high risk and locally advanced in just two years? By a urologist who was not entirely honest with the patient. He made no attempt whatsoever to INFORM me of the possibility of a false negative biopsy. He only told me that my biopsy was negative and that my prostate was normal. In my mind, performing a biopsy that completely missed a sizable tumor should be grounds for a lawsuit. But of course that would likely be a futile effort and would just make me feel worse. And so because two years were lost, I am basically now an incontinent eunuch with major depressive disorder. I certainly hope you don't end up that way. I always assumed that a doctor would know what he's doing and that he would act only in the patient's best interest. Not so. Thank you for your reply. Im very sorry this happened to you. I wish I had some magic wand to make it all better for you but can only offer my prayers and artfully dealt sarcastic wit. The pirads 3/4 they identified is in the right peripheral lobe and should have been reachable, I think. My last biopsy showed inflammation and prostatitis and some other benign condition but I dont have the report to tell me where those samples hit. If they were in the right peripheral the 3/4 that showed up on the MRI might be what was found last time. Hang in there my friend.
Posts.Title: Question about biopsy changes

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Ready2Fight Yes for us. First biopsy came back negative and my husband was ready to celebrate... not so fast Mr. MRI guided biopsy found it in the hard to reach anterior and there was plenty of it. Pathology later revealed that 35% of his prostate was cancerous all while his first biopsy came back showing none. I guess if theres anything that gives me hope of a benign answer, the Pirads 3/4 which was found is in the right peripheral lobe. So I Would think that it wouldve been easily reachable during the first biopsy and during a DRE. So I find a little encouragement and that the worst thing found on the MRI wasnt in the base up hidden behind the pelvic bone or something like that. But time will tail, Ill deal with whatever comes up. My best to you and your husband

Posts.Content: Hi all, Nervously awaiting my biopsy results and a question popped into my head that I dont think was ever asked. I know plenty of you have had negative original biopsies only to have a later positive biopsy. However, has anyone had the situation where the first biopsy result was totally clear and a later biopsy showed a surprising amount of cancer? My original biopsy was March of last year and was complete clear. Im wondering what to expect from these fusion results...I would expect that just a year later if there is any cancer at all it should be relatively localizedperhaps in the PIRADS 3/4 area. I would be a little surprised if the 12 core random biopsy samples they took after the fusion came back with significant cancer in degree or quantity. Basically my interpretation of the clean biopsy from last March was that it could only say that My prostate wasnt completely eaten up with cancer. Just curious if anyone had the surprise lots of cancer on a second biopsy. Am I making any sense what so ever?

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by HighlanderCFH Welcome aboard to BOTH of you. Ice, I believe your uro is probably correct that this is NOT a case of prostate cancer, but the result of a steadily growing prostate. Prostate tissue creates PSA and, of course, larger prostates produce more PSA. Normal PSA readings for the 40s age group is 0 - 2.5. You're approaching the age group of the 50s, for which the range is 0 - 3.5. So you're not horribly far from the high norm. In addition, your PSA elevation has been a slow, steady increase over the past few years, which kind of dovetails with your BPH. You'll probably be just fine -- but will be in a situation where I was at in that an enlarged prostate/higher PSA could someday be masking a tumor, which would probably be reflected by a rapid spike in the PSA reading. This means that you'll want to have regular PSA tests from now on to keep an eye on things. Good luck! Chuck Thanks Chuck, very helpful. You may be completely and totally wrong and I might have a raging case of PC, but your response will help me get through this nightmare. I alternate from I feel absolutely fine and have next to no symptoms to I cant breathe Im so scared. Little area in between.

Posts.Title: Scared to death.....

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by HighlanderCFH Welcome aboard to BOTH of you. Ice, I believe your uro is probably correct that this is NOT a case of prostate cancer, but the result of a steadily growing prostate. Prostate tissue creates PSA and, of course, larger prostates produce more PSA. Normal PSA readings for the 40s age group is 0 - 2.5. You're approaching the age group of the 50s, for which the range is 0 - 3.5. So you're not horribly far from the high norm. In addition, your PSA elevation has been a slow, steady increase over the past few years, which kind of dovetails with your BPH. You'll probably be just fine -- but will be in a situation where I was at in that an enlarged prostate/higher PSA could someday be masking a tumor, which would probably be reflected by a rapid spike in the PSA reading. This means that you'll want to have regular PSA tests from now on to keep an eye on things. Good luck! Chuck Thanks Chuck, very helpful. You may be completely and totally wrong and I might have a raging case of PC, but your response will help me get through this nightmare. I alternate from I feel absolutely fine and have next to no symptoms to I cant breathe Im so scared. Little area in between.

Posts.Title: Scared to death.....

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Michael F Welcome ISZ! First & Foremost: Relax & Do NOT Panic! While we are not MDs and can not make predictions, I can assure you that all of us share the opinion that You will be around for a long time. Some points to consider: - You are young. Men in their 40's can/do get PCa but it is far more prevalent with men in their 60's. Thus the statistics are in your favor. - You prostate gland is large. The Ultrasound is not as accurate as an MRI in measuring prostate volume. So yours may actually be larger than 46 cc. - You PSA is definitely elevated and rising. However, the rate of rise is NOT meteoric which is good. - 10% Free PSA is concerning but in now way diagnostic of PCa - Your URO MD does not seem suspect PCa so neither should you! Did the URO MD not inject your prostate with lidocaine prior to biopsy? On the long list of Things No Man Has Ever Said is: "I really relaxed & enjoyed the time between walking into my Urologist's office to have my biopsy and returning a week later for the results!" Good luck and best wishes for walking out of the office next visit with all good results! Be sure to get a copy of the Path Report for your records. Keep us updated. MF Thanks for the reassurance. Consensus seems to be Im okay so Im holding you all to that! ðŸ˜€ He did inject it with lidocain and once he did, it was fine. In fact I told him to take extra samples if he wanted because I wanted to be sure. I felt one minor twinge on one of the samples. The problem was getting the thing in there. Not sure how others are but this thing was shaped like a longer, large Nintendo Wii controller. I first thought awesome, while waiting for the Xanax to kick in were going to play Wii golf. No were gonna play hide this giant brick sized ultrasound and knife attack machine in there. It was a bit of a struggle because theres just no way to relax during THAT! But I got through it and then stumbled around like a cast member of the walking dead at the bagel shop. I dont remember a thing about that experience but am in intensive therapy trying to forget the biopsy. ðŸ˜€ I think Im going to fire my primary care doc and write him a letter informing him why and what he should be doing for other patients on TRT. And technically for men not on TRT, if their velocity increases like mine. .5 is apparently a pretty reliabile indicator of high probability of cancer. The good news is that unless I crash, I plan to be off the TRT. Hated being dependent on that stuff and hoping that each insurer plan covers it.

Posts.Title: Scared to death.....

Posts.Content: Oh yeah, sorry one more thing..... I believe at some point the androgel stopped working or stopped being effective and my body started its own T production again. I stopped the androgel over 2 weeks ago and I feel better than ever. I'm anxious as can be about this chance of cancer but my sex life is better than it has been in forever (feel real desire again and morning erections). My mind is a little foggier but energy is fine. I have a STRONG belief that I was converting much of the androgel to estrogen. My urologist said on androgel stopping cold turkey, I should see any crash within a few days....but I feel fine. If this turns out to be BPH this might save me a lot of mess and money!
Posts.Title: Scared to death.....

Posts.Content: Thanks guys. I have pretty good insurance so generally if there is a good doctor they will be on my plan. If not I have some back door ways. So I think that I can just about get any doc in the Atlanta area. I thought I was with the best practice but have just been through a whole lot of wth with them of late. Ive kind of lost trust in them. But unlike other states that have their premier programs, I dont really know of a leader in Atlanta metro area.
Posts.Title: Atlanta/metro Atlanta urologist referral?

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by DjinTonic The best medicine now is to relax!! If it's cancer you will deal with it and be done. If it's not, your doc will look elsewhere for any symptoms you're having. It's possible that there are repeat biopsies in your future. Imaging, especially newer PET scans, are improving and are starting to be used for diagnosis. After my I-don't-remember-which-number negative biopsy, my doc said "We are not going to let you die of high-grade cancer."Turns out we subsequently did find very high-grade cancer. The good news is that he's kept his promise so far: I'm alive and typing. Glad to hear it....glad you made it brother. Thats the funny thing up until I got that Ill fated email from my pcp this time last year I never had the first symptom of any significance. So theres not much to treat. I do have some Ed but I think thats because they stopped the testosterone replacement and might be BPH related to some extent. But even thats manageable. Remember that 80s shirt Frankie says relax, well I used to say Frankie needs his butt whipped. Relaxing is not my thing...certainly not right now. But Ill try to as best I can.
Posts.Title: Question about biopsy changes

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Maximus It looks like I've settled on a hospital and surgeon. I am getting ready to schedule my radical prostatectomy and was curious - how much time did it take for you to schedule your surgery? How far out was your surgeon scheduling? I'm just trying to get a sense for how long I will have to wait. My cancer is aggressive - Gleason score of 8 - and I need to have surgery ASAP. Thanks. Good for you, youre one more step away from being done with this headache. Just a side note meant for humor. Why do they call it a radical anything....why not a simple prostatectomy or a nothing to worry about prostatectomy. I got it, a walk in the park prostatectomy! ðŸ˜€

Posts.Title: Time to Schedule Surgery

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by pplexed I am a 41 year old male. My psa history is as follows: 07/12-1.27, 12/17-2.90, 1/17-2.40. 2/18-1.90, 2/19-3.50 (Free 0.49) percentage 14%.. My ExoDX Prostate Intelliscore-51.71-2/18. I had an MP-MRI at Johns Hopkins in April 04/18 which showed no lesion, and two areas identified as possible Prostatitis with a PIRADS score of 2. However, my current PSA as of yesterday is 3.5 with a free PSA of 0.49, and a percentage at 14%, is quite concerning for agressive PCA at 41 years of age. I do not have any symptoms indicating a prostate infection. What are the forums thoughts? Dont spend all your retirement $ just yet. Your numbers are a lot like mine but Im 48. Ive had a random 12 core that was all clean and just had a fusion biopsy after I had a pirads 3/4 in my MRI. On the fusion 14 samples (12 random and 2 focused) 12 came back clean and 2 came back as precancerous. Your numbers arent that bad and can be explained away by prostatitis and/or BPH. I would want a biopsy if it were my prostate. It just adds a measure of extra assurance.

Posts.Title: 41 with a PIRADS-2/ PSA 3.5 14% free, and a ExoDx score of 51.71=High Grade Cancer?

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by DjinTonic In addition to cores taken in any areas the mpMRI identified as suspicious, a fusion biopsy usually includes the 12 cores taken randomly throughout the prostate. They aren't always exactly random, because the uro can sometimes see things that look suspicious in the ultrasound used to guide the biopsy needle. That is what mine did they apparently have an ultrasound machine so Advanced that it rivals identification of cancer as the MRI. My doc took a while with that whiffleball bat so Im hoping that his results were good and very thorough.
Posts.Title: 41 with a PIRADS-2/ PSA 3.5 14% free, and a ExoDx score of 51.71=High Grade Cancer?

Posts.Content: Hi all, I'm new here and terrified (have those words ever been uttered here? ). Trying desperately to keep some perspective, while I wait two more days for my biopsy results. I'm 47 years old and went on Androgel about, I don't know, 10-12 years ago because my T levels were 260 at age 37 or 38. Ummm worked okay I guess--super expensive and a pain to administer/deal with. Life bumped along until two weeks ago when I did some routine bloodwork and received a message from my primary care doc who had been measuring my PSA. It had bounced to 4.1 which exceeded the high end level. He apparently had been asleep at the wheel (I had no idea about PSA velocity or rising PSA), here are my PSA levels by year: 2012: 2.2 2013: 2.6 2014: 2.8 2015: 3.1 2016: 3.5 2017: ? I don't have a copy, I'm SURE we measured it. 2018: 4.1 He should have clued in something was wrong, so I referred to a urologist immediately and stopped the androgel. The doc said androgel probably wouldn't cause the high reading but might just accelerate the trajectory of where my prostate was going anyway. Family history: Dad aged 75 has the prostate of a 25 year old. Half brother, nothing. DRE showed a larger than average prostate (but I'm a big guy, 6'3" 295) that subsequently measured 46 ML on an ultrasound--large prostate, lots of PSA. The prostate was smooth, no nodules or bumps. On the ultrasound the doc said he saw no signs of odd density or oddities, nothing to worry about from the ultrasound. The doctor measured my free PSA that measured at 10% that gave me >50% chance of cancer until you discounted my age. The doc plugged my numbers into his handy dandy calculator and told me 75% chance it's BPH and 25% and chance it's cancer. He said his threshold to 'wait and see' was 20%, so being the worry wart I am I opted for the biopsy. No anesthesia but he gave me 30 mg of Xanax that kicked in about 30 minutes AFTER the biopsy was over, I hear I enjoyed the bagel my wife bought me on the way home (don't remember it). But I remember every SECOND of that barbaric biopsy. Anyway, that's it. The doctor said he believes it will ultimately be BPH but I'm just scared to death that it's cancer. The doctor said that even if it was cancer, it's 87% chance it's NOT the aggressive kill you type and that he'd get rid of it and the ride to the doctor's office would be riskier than the cancer...with regards to my life. I go Thursday (two days from now) to get the results and I'm having trouble eating and sleeping worrying about this. A wife and a college freshman and high school freshman, I have a lot of people who need me around.

Posts.Title: 41 with a PIRADS-2/ PSA 3.5 14% free, and a ExoDx score of 51.71=High Grade Cancer?

Posts.Content: Hey my friend, I havent had an RP (yet, but it seems inevitable). But Ive had some depressive episodes due to stress overload at times. If youre prone to it maybe join a local cancer support group as sometimes talking through things will help. There are a lot of new SSRIs and non-SSRI drugs that are new and great. Just be patient and know it may take a few trials before you find yours. The best help I had was from a local church who offers ministry services with licensed psychologists. The one I saw helped me immensely. And it was free. I liked the fact that he focused on causation vs just issuing drugs. Thats all I have to help other than my prayers. Im 48 and really sweating this fusion biopsy result that should be in mid-week. I might be right behind you. Prayers out for you my friend.

Posts.Title: Depression after RP

Posts.Content: Good stuff, thank you
Posts.Title: Good TED talk

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Semiramide IMO Mr Jim McCarthy falls perilously close to the category of charlatan. He should have never been allowed on stage to give a TED Talk related to being diagnosed with prostate cancer. He is on AS! He has not been affected by Prostate Cancer except for his self proclaimed grossly inappropriate psychological impacts of a disease status that is most likely 100% harmless to him. He received a gift diagnosis not a death sentence! He has not experienced any of the following either individually or in combination: Radiation Therapy, Radical Prostatectomy Surgery, Hormone Therapy; Radical Prostatectomy Surgery followed by Radiation Therapy, Any of these combined with Hormone Therapy, incontinence, erectile dysfunction, loss of masculinity during treatment and obviously not death by prostate cancer. No, he experienced no pain or suffering. He has never had to battle the disease. Rather he used his "misfortune" to snag a new girlfriend and ride off to a new start in his blue convertible. Get out the puke bags buddy!!! Instead Mr McCarthy stands in the spotlight and insipidly spews out a theme stolen from the great Al Greene: Love and Happiness. What a misguided total fool! What an insult to the members of this forum who have been truly impacted by prostate cancer. Sorry Mr SubDenis but you should remove the link to Mr McCarthy's shameful self-aggrandizing charade. Nevermind...
Posts.Title: Good TED talk

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by KarlEmagne IceStationZebra, all the best with your results, I'll be thinking of you in the hope it helps. Yes, I should look for a local cancer support group! Lastchance, I lately found a nice congregation close by lifting my spirits even though I'm not a firm believer either. Depressive episodes are like heart attacks; people that had some are much more likely to get more. Especially if there's a triggering event, such as sudden affliction with frustrating chronic illness. I took fluoxetine 20mg for several weeks and the issue wasn't that the drug didn't have any effects. It increased my clumsiness, caused strange headaches, and most importantly destabilized me. I flipped from seeing pink elephants to miserable or irritable with disorganization and crappy ideas in very short time. Did more harm than good. Possible there are now better medications on the market, but they should be chosen with care and I'm not too confident, judging from experience, that the public health system will provide this service should I need it post-OP. Honestly, all of this is just such a nightmare. KarlEmagne, yes it is a nightmare. Thanks for the positive thoughts. I told my wife that its like some really well directed movies where you learn and associate with the main character and you feel trapped right along with them in their circumstances. Training Day is one instance, I felt completely trapped with Ethan Hawked character. The only difference is we dont get to turn the channel or pick a romantic comedy! ðŸ˜€ Hang in there brother. Definitely try out a new antidepressant for the short term. There are several that are new and good. I took generic Prozac and really didnt want to stop except it caused a little weight gain. Made me crave carbs..all the carbs. But it gave me the most elaborate and beautiful dreams that seemed to go on forever like a long movie. After my mom died I had a long conversation with her in heaven...she was healthy and could breathe again and that was a gift. Good luck buddy, there are people who have so many uncurable cancers...were the lucky ones if you can call it luck. Most of us have a positive future, just a semi rough road to hoe to get to it.
Posts.Title: Depression after RP

Posts.Content: I have a 3t MRI on Monday and am a little concerned about it. Ive had two MRIs before on my shoulders. The first (after injecting the contrast) they put this scaled down hula hoop over my head to check for fit. I had about 3 of shoulders on each side outside. So it was either reschedule to the larger opening machine or make sausage out of me. They strapped the shoulder being MRId down and used a towel to wrap my free arm like a straight jacket. I was still scraping the sides of the machine so they had to move me in a few inches and let me wiggle and then they moved me some more. It was harrowing. The second was a wider machine and I did a little better but I could still look down and see a little daylight. Im scheduled for the larger machine but am a little concerned about being stuck that far in the machine. Does your head go in first and if so, do you end up with your head outside the other side? Or are you truly coffind in there?

Posts.Title: How bad is the MRI?

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by RobLee I had a MRI of the head and neck about a year ago and they put me in this headgear to keep my head motionless and had an angled mirror something like a periscope in front of my eyes so that I was looking down at my feet and out into the room. Also took an Ativan beforehand. I think that was my fourth MRI, but have had many CT's which of course go much faster fortunately. Three just this year, including a brain scan, plus an "octreoscan" radio isotope scan that took 90 minutes in the machine with my arms over my head... twice! My arms were shaking like a leaf by the end of it. The MRI was a piece of cake. I took a Xanax to take the edge off although in hind sight I was still able to see daylight so I was fine. Now the excruciating wait to early /mid January starts.

Posts.Content: Hey my friend, I havent had an RP (yet, but it seems inevitable). But Ive had some depressive episodes due to stress overload at times. If youre prone to it maybe join a local cancer support group as sometimes talking through things will help. There are a lot of new SSRIs and non-SSRI drugs that are new and great. Just be patient and know it may take a few trials before you find yours. The best help I had was from a local church who offers ministry services with licensed psychologists. The one I saw helped me immensely. And it was free. I liked the fact that he focused on causation vs just issuing drugs. Thats all I have to help other than my prayers. Im 48 and really sweating this fusion biopsy result that should be in mid-week. I might be right behind you. Prayers out for you my friend.

AgeInfo.Phrase: <Z> <Z> <Z> <Z> Im 48 and really sweating this fusion

Posts.Title: Depression after RP

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by KarlEmagne IceStationZebra, all the best with your results, I'll be thinking of you in the hope it helps. Yes, I should look for a local cancer support group! Lastchance, I lately found a nice congregation close by lifting my spirits even though I'm not a firm believer either. Depressive episodes are like heart attacks; people that had some are much more likely to get more. Especially if there's a triggering event, such as sudden affliction with frustrating chronic illness. I took fluoxetine 20mg for several weeks and the issue wasn't that the drug didn't have any effects. It increased my clumsiness, caused strange headaches, and most importantly destabilized me. I flipped from seeing pink elephants to miserable or irritable with disorganization and crappy ideas in very short time. Did more harm than good. Possible there are now better medications on the market, but they should be chosen with care and I'm not too confident, judging from experience, that the public health system will provide this service should I need it post-OP. Honestly, all of this is just such a nightmare. KarlEmagne, yes it is a nightmare. Thanks for the positive thoughts. I told my wife that its like some really well directed movies where you learn and associate with the main character and you feel trapped right along with them in their circumstances. Training Day is one instance, I felt completely trapped with Ethan Hawked character. The only difference is we dont get to turn the channel or pick a romantic comedy! ðŸ˜€ Hang in there brother. Definitely try out a new antidepressant for the short term. There are several that are new and good. I took generic Prozac and really didnt want to stop except it caused a little weight gain. Made me crave carbs..all the carbs. But it gave me the most elaborate and beautiful dreams that seemed to go on forever like a long movie. After my mom died I had a long conversation with her in heaven...she was healthy and could breathe again and that was a gift. Good luck buddy, there are people who have so many uncurable cancers...were the lucky ones if you can call it luck. Most of us have a positive future, just a semi rough road to hoe to get to it.

Posts.Title: Depression after RP

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by charles384 I just had a MRI on Dec 12. They put me in head first and I was able to see outside that end. Of course they tell you not to move and they put something across the prostate area. Other than the hammering noise and a hard place on the table where my right arm was, nothing to it. I was in 45 minutes and closed my eyes and took a nap. Didn't even know when they injected the contrast thru the IV inside my elbow. So if you can get past the noise, you will do fine. Yeah the noise is not a big deal at all. I just cant stand the feeling that Im being buried in a coffin. So much that Im going the Dwight Schrute way of having someone plug me a time or two with a shotgun right before they bury me. Just to make sure! ðŸ˜€ On the first one they actually showed me a movie. On the second one, no headset so when I opened my eyes and saw that taupe colored machine I lost depth perception, it was like a Hitchcock movie where it felt like the machine was surging towards my face and backing away and forward and back! I think that as long as I can see some kind of daylight Ill be fine. The only other thing is that Im there for prostate problems so I know that as soon as they strap me in, Ill need to pee. Thank for the info!

Posts.Title: Depression after RP

Posts.Content: I have a 3t MRI on Monday and am a little concerned about it. Ive had two MRIs before on my shoulders. The first (after injecting the contrast) they put this scaled down hula hoop over my head to check for fit. I had about 3 of shoulders on each side outside. So it was either reschedule to the larger opening machine or make sausage out of me. They strapped the shoulder being MRId down and used a towel to wrap my free arm like a straight jacket. I was still scraping the sides of the machine so they had to move me in a few inches and let me wiggle and then they moved me some more. It was harrowing. The second was a wider machine and I did a little better but I could still look down and see a little daylight. Im scheduled for the larger machine but am a little concerned about being stuck that far in the machine. Does your head go in first and if so, do you end up with your head outside the other side? Or are you truly coffind in there?

Posts.Title: How bad is the MRI?

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by OldTiredSailor I can certainly understand and identify with your concern. I've had many, dozens ?, of MRIs over the years due to bad back, knees, shoulder, neck. During the first ?? (many over the years) I never had a claustrophobia problem. I'd spent years crawling around very tight pipes, tunnels, and engine rooms with no thought of a problem. Then suddenly, about 2003, I became extremely claustrophobic during an MRI for my back. (I was 30-minutes into the MRI, which was an old style narrow tube with a closed end where your head ended up for a back image. I was listening to classical music and was half asleep when the technician says "Boy am I glad you are not claustrophobic - it is a real nuisance when people freak out in there." I quickly lost it! My heart accelerated, my breathing almost stopped and I started sweating like crazy. As I recall I made it thru that one but the next several MRIs were downright frightening.) Since that time MRIs, CT scans, and radionuclide cardiac stress tests (the sensor presses on your chest) have been a real issue for me and cause me a lot of stress leading up to the event. My 3T mpMRI (June this year) for the prostate was in a newer Siemens machine and it was a whole lot LESS problematic (scary!) than the older enclosed machines. The tunnel is wide open at both ends and is at least 50% wider than the older style. They put me in feet first so that my shoulders and head were outside the tube. Additionally, and most important for my mental state, I had to keep my arms above my head while lying there. My claustrophia is worst when I feel like my arms and hands are pinned in such a fashion I cannot help myself ESCAPE. The machine used for my 3T mpMRI did not cause that irrational sensation. AND, my GP has given me an Rx for Adivan 0.5mg (Lorazepam), which is a very mild anti-anxiety medication. I take one 90-minutes before they put me in the tube and I feel almost NO concerns and can even fall asleep if the technician does not talk to me. I also feel no effect from the Adivan, it does not seem to make my thinking slow or cloudy and does not seem to impair my judgement, or at least my wife says she cannot tell when I take it. They snatched victory from the jaws of defeat! ðŸ˜€

Posts.Title: Pathology Results

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Firemedic54 I had prostate cancer surgery on October of 2016. Have had PSA of 0 on all follow up blood work. I have been having some issues lately with fatigue, low libido, no energy. I had my doctor check my testosterone levels and it was 238. I have an appointment scheduled for next week to discuss options. Everything I can find by searching says that there is no increase in PSA going up after testosterone treatment in former cancer patients. Does anyone have any experience in this? I want to feel better but I don't want to do anything detrimental to my health. This relevant to my interests. I believe that my doctors said that he would not be comfortable putting me back on testosterone unless I ultimately needed an RP and then it didnt matter provided I was clear of cancer after the surgery. Right now he has me in clomid to naturally stimulate some testosterone. I was at 277 after stopping testosterone replacement. I had the same issues as you and really am still having them under my own bodys natural production. Ed is a real problem right now and wasnt when on the external testosterone.
Posts.Title: Testosterone after prostate cancer?

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Another Be careful. You are both young to be presenting with PC. If you were both on testosterone supplements it may be viewed suspiciously as the source of your PC presenting early. I have heard it's influence can be for early, small, and aggressive cancers. Nobody knows what is normal for testosterone. Everyone wants what testosterone provides; energy, vitality, libido, limber, erections, muscle mass, etc. Who wouldn't, but at what price? Professional advice from Mayo is to not use testosterone supplements to counter normal aging. There have been studies that confuse this issue. What we do know. One proven treatment for advanced prostate cancer is to effectively use drug therapy to reduce testosterone to very low levels and force/stun prostate cancer into remission. The implication in this proven treatment is PC responds to testosterone. It can respond and adjust to manipualtion of testosterone and become resistant to it or continue to thrive at varying levels. It's a wild card. It's use now may affect use later when you may really need it. My advice, unless you have a life threatening issue addressed by testosterone supplementation it is safer to avoid it unless neccesary to combat PC. I am no expert in this, but when I hear talk of experimenting with it in the presence of PC the hair on my neck goes up. Especially, when it's use may have been the source of it presenting as it has. Nobody can claim you are clear of cancer, now or after RP. The commercialized pressure through advertising to influence patients to ask doctors for certain drug therapies seems to cause some doctors to throw up their hands and let you have your way. Sort of an eyes wide open, except you really don't know. You just want to be young again. The symptoms of testosterone use are many. Im curious would you lump the use of clomid which fools my brain into making testosterone of its own in the same vein? Weve adjusted me to like a 500-550 range not bodybuilder level just so that I can have some energy, stamina and libido. I get what you are saying but are all the guys on this board taking the medication that stops their own testosterone production? Boy talk about the walking dead. I get not throwing on the external sources testosterone if you have cancer but naturally producing it via clomid is not the same as what youre talking right?

Posts.Title: Testosterone after prostate cancer?

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Firemedic54 I am looking for just a jump in mine to get it back to the low normal. I don't need to 800-1000. Just looking for what is in the normal range. Your body is supposed to already be there. There are definite problems with chronically low testosterone including heart disease and diabetes. There is some evidence that it can also worsen asthma. I can understand for a short period of time while treating pca but life without testosterone is barely better than death. At my lowest I couldnt even mow my front yard (20 minutes max) without taking four or five breaks because it was like I had the flu.

Posts.Content: Well the good news is that I drink skim milk. Ive been on a bender lately. But I need to cut down.
Posts.Title: PCa and dairy.

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by DjinTonic See the above study regarding skim -- nothing but skim in our house, and only for cereal and as an ingredient in some recipes. While humans are definitely omnivores (and therefore meat-eaters), evolution will only get you to the age of reproduction and child care, after that, all bets are off, as is the case for otherwise healthy foods that (later) contribute to cancer risk. On the flip side, when my sister, then a vegetarian, was pregnant with her first child, her OB was not happy and wanted her to add meat back to her diet. Well, I dont have a definitive diagnosis yet...may be as early as Wednesday or if I get lucky and this fusion biopsy is clean, until my next biopsy. Based on all Ive learned here, it seems like a matter of time. Im 48 so I think the chances that I end up with BPH for 30-40 years without it turning to cancer is zippo. Anyway, Im the same size as my dad was at the same age and have exactly the same diet. In fact, I would say I eat healthier than he ever did and exercise whereas he didnt. He has the prostate of a 21 year old and PSA in the 1s at 75. My half brother has brain cancer but no prostate problems. Im unaware of anyone in the family who had prostate issues of any kind. No one. So somewhere this has to be plain old dna recessive genes or something. I just dont get it. But man, when youre thirsty a good cold glass of milk is just sooooo good.

Posts.Title: PCa and dairy.

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by DjinTonic A recent study hypothesizes a PCa-protective effect for BPH and a mechanism for it. I believe the incidence of PCa in men with BPH is lower that in men without it. You could make the case that without my 20+ years of BPH, I would have wound up with cancer earlier than I did, as opposed to BPH being a contributing factor. Interesting, when I think I have it all figured out...I learn more. It seems Ive read it both ways. Something I read seemed to indicate BPH being a contributing factor for PCA. But I like your explanation better.

Why not a Rate you Prostate Biopsy at the department Exit door? The grading buttons would be located right at the sign that says "How did we do...do today? This infantile humor is on my mind because I'm currently studying hard (soft?) for my colonoscopy exam, appropriately scheduled (??) tomorrow, on Valentine's Day (!). Well I dont want to speak Ill of the doctor as there are so many variables. But there is no damned way that I will go through that process awake again. Im off this week but Im going down to whomever is in charge of making these decisions and theyre going to get an earful from me about refusal to pay for anesthesia for this barbaric procedure. I work for my insurer. I guarantee you that whomever made that decision never had a biopsy.

You could make the case that without my 20+ years of BPH, I would have wound up with cancer earlier than I did, as opposed to BPH being a contributing factor. Interesting, when I think I have it all figured out...I learn more. It seems Ive read it both ways. Something I read seemed to indicate BPH being a contributing factor for PCA. But I like your explanation better.

He wanted me to become a vegan five days a week and eat meat two days (but no red meat those days). Sorry freaking doctor now all I want is milk, I crave it like a pregnant woman ! ðŸ˜€ He claims the animal proteins will fuel future cancer. Not sure of his source.

Posts.Content: Well the good news is that I drink skim milk. Ive been on a bender lately. But I need to cut down.
Posts.Title: PCa and dairy.

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by DjinTonic Very true: as in my case, BPH with a continuously but slowly rising PSA rise will likely mean repeat biopsies are in your future. And the path report at surgery can find both down- and up-grading of the Gleason score assigned at biopsy (which is why G6 men need to be cautious and adhere to their AS protocols if they are candidates). On the other hand for the rest of us guys, treatment means treatment, and we have to play the pathological cards we are dealt. Yeah its definitely frustrating. If I were older..maybe late 60s or even in my 70s I might just have it yanked out at the first signgiven the inability to be sure how bad and where the cancer really is. I figure by that time my wife wont want to fool around with my old wrinkly self so she wouldnt miss it so much. But Im 48. To lose sex at this age would be devastating to both of us. Yeah I expect Ill be doing biopsies every year or two going forward. I might also need a urolift procedure to alleviate any urinary symptoms. Im not really having any now...until the blood clot suddenly clogs the pipe momentarily. Thankfully it was only for a second before I had the chance to point it at myself to see what was what. ðŸ˜€

Posts.Title: So what happens to men with an initial negative biopsy?

Posts.Content: I have a coworker...staff member actually. We talked about prostate issues previously and he said he had issues and was taking flowmax. So I figured he was in good care. He told me two days ago that his GP had told him his prostate had grown since the last exam. He apparently wasnt regularly seeing the urologist. I asked what the GP said or did, he doubled his flowmax. What the heck? The GP has watched his PSA in the high 3s for years and said nothing. So I asked him what his urologist said at the last visit and he said he told me you dont have prostate cancer, dont worry. So he stopped going. That might not sound that terribly bad until you realize the poor guy is 42 or 43 years old. African American. His PSA has been in the upper 3s for years. It was 3.7 at last years check. Oh yeah and no family history unless you count both his dad and his uncle on his fathers side who had prostate cancer. Oh and the urologist proclaimed he didnt have cancer without doing free PSA, pca3, 4K, an MRI or a BIOPSY. For the love of all thats good and holy...hes been failed by both doctors in a very bad way. How can that urologist even make that comment with no factual testing basis? I sat him down and explained the things I could and gave him a roadmap of what Ive done and been through. I tried to impart the gravity of what he could be facing without terrifying him, but hes motivated now. I gave him my doctors name but warned him about the office staff. He needs some immediate help and a biopsy. What is wrong with these doctors?

Posts.Title: What dietary supplements do you guys thnik will help

Posts.Content: Well Im back.... that was hell. First, surprise cystoscopy. It wasnt painful but burned a lot and was uncomfortable. No one told me I was having it. The good news they use a very high definition camera and said the bladder and prostate couldnt look better. No cancer present there. The prostate looked good and healthy, just big. Then the biopsy. First the Dre, third doc in the practice to do it (for variety) and all said that it felt big but perfect, no lumps anywhere. But man, I think he knocked a crown out with that biopsy wand. My first 12 core I remember three distinct snaps and felt nothing. This time there were 14 or more individual snaps and I felt everything. Now for the bad part, I was supposed to be asleep but they had me awake. I took 30 mg of Valium and was completely unaffected. I proved it to them by walking a line like I was being given a dui check. In fact I could have driven home just fine, Valium apparently doesnt affect me. So I went through that solo. Now the wait begins. But Im glad thats over...this time I have a ton of pain, just a throbbing pain that Tylenol isnt helping. Just rambling, talking helps.
Posts.Title: Back from fusion biopsy

Posts.Title: PCa and dairy.

Posts.Content: Remember when Desean Jackson spiked the ball on the 1 yard line? ðŸ˜€....that was me. I was in the end zone doing my victory dance when I heard the announcer! This is all so confusing, its like dating. No means yes, just later. Yes means something. Kind of a gland with no answers. Negative biopsy (even subsequent biopsies) really cant help you sleep at night. Positive tests really muddy the waters because you cant know for sure if what was found was the entirety of the tumor and the correct grade. Very frustrating. When you throw in people who are unlucky enough to have BPH the waters get even more muddy.
Posts.Title: So what happens to men with an initial negative biopsy?

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Duck2 While I agree your co-worker needs a Uro, assuming the PSA is or is not cancer with values in the 3s is not a valid. Heck, I have a PSA of 5.11 and I know a high number of people my age with higher values seeing their URO with no biopsy. 90% of the biopsies come back negative. Because there is no cancer, BPH,and the needles missing the lesions when there is. That is what ISO PSA test is supposed to due - eliminate unneeded biopsies. Yes to clarify I didnt tell him that he had pca just that his PSA was way too high...should be 2.0 or lower. My point was that there should have been red flashing red lights abs sirens going offf. And he should have had a biopsy long ago. How is it these gps are so clueless?

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by garyi Any photos you wish to share, Michael? At least you didn't have the stress in anticipation of a cystoscopy, ISZ. Your doctors are being very thorough, and any discomfort should subside very soon....frozen pees, or not. Good luck with getting some excellent news from your tests! Do you guys think that Id really stress and worry about the cystoscopy if I knew about it? ðŸ˜€. (This is where we all throw our heads back and laugh). Im actually glad they did it , but I was already perturbed because I was fully awake and knew I was going to hate this day. Thanks all for the idea, Im sitting on an ice pack now. Took a short nap and upon awaking, I am in misery. This is a totally different experience than last time. Last time I had no pain to mention and now I can barely sit still. It seems to be getting worse instead of better. I cant not worry but I take pain incredibly well. But this is not quite beyond what I can stand but is approaching it quickly.

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by DjinTonic See the above study regarding skim -- nothing but skim in our house, and only for cereal and as an ingredient in some recipes. While humans are definitely omnivores (and therefore meat-eaters), evolution will only get you to the age of reproduction and child care, after that, all bets are off, as is the case for otherwise healthy foods that (later) contribute to cancer risk. On the flip side, when my sister, then a vegetarian, was pregnant with her first child, her OB was not happy and wanted her to add meat back to her diet. Well, I dont have a definitive diagnosis yet...may be as early as Wednesday or if I get lucky and this fusion biopsy is clean, until my next biopsy. Based on all Ive learned here, it seems like a matter of time. Im 48 so I think the chances that I end up with BPH for 30-40 years without it turning to cancer is zippo. Anyway, Im the same size as my dad was at the same age and have exactly the same diet. In fact, I would say I eat healthier than he ever did and exercise whereas he didnt. He has the prostate of a 21 year old and PSA in the 1s at 75. My half brother has brain cancer but no prostate problems. Im unaware of anyone in the family who had prostate issues of any kind. No one. So somewhere this has to be plain old dna recessive genes or something. I just dont get it. But man, when youre thirsty a good cold glass of milk is just sooooo good.

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by DjinTonic Ice, it was probably better that the cystoscopy was a surprise--one less thing to worry about beforehand. Your painful/little pain biopsy experiences gives credence to my feeling that docs have varying skill with the nerve block injections at the start of the procedure. Done successfully, you feel each snap, but no real pain--gradually the discomfort builds as the total insult to the prostate increases and the cores near the nerve plexuses. Best of luck for good biopsy results! Djin Yes, I feel like the original doc from my first biopsy was much better. The experiences were night and day.

Im off this week but Im going down to whomever is in charge of making these decisions and theyre going to get an earful from me about refusal to pay for anesthesia for this barbaric procedure. I think one of the underlying reasons that my doc is looking at treatment sooner than later is my family history of prostate cancer. My dad and all three of his brothers have had their prostates removed along with his mom and sister having breast cancer. I believe I have a significant target on my back. IÃ‚ll have a more in depth conversation with my doc after my next psa. I have been trying to get ahead on the kegel exercises when I remember. I need to come up with something to remind me to do them at certain times of the day. That makes sense. Sorry to hear but Ive said it several times that my real personal risk is under treating pca based on finding only a G6 when there could be G7-G9 hidden in there. I would have a real time accepting the fact that I was too conservative with AS for too long and let something get out of control. At our age the oddswith cancer already foundof dying with our prostate on board are low. Best of luck to you.
Posts.Title: Nearing the end of active surveillance

Posts.Content: Whats up fellas and ladies? Well Im back. Dont worry those who might remember me and think oh no, hes back and probably has cancer. Well thatd be a good guess and who knows whether youre right and whether youre wrong? ðŸ˜€ Well initially I started this journey with a 4.1 PSA and 10% free PSA and then had a 12 core biopsy that came back all negative. That was six months ago. Had my six month follow up today and my PSA sadly hit 4.4 so thats a .3 rise in only six months....extrapolated thats .6 in a year. DRE was fine, no problems. So the doctor ordered the pca3 test. If it comes back positive thats a pretty good indication that I have some cancer that was missed by the biopsy. If so, theres some MRI combined with some sort of ultrasound that will help them find the cancer and eliminate it and around and around we go. So I dont know much more but after stopping TRT I hoped the PSA would fall and I could quit wondering. Too long didnt read? I dont know squat...still.

Yep I eliminated all prostat irritating activities for a week before except for my job! ðŸ˜€. It was the same lab. This is the most frustrating gland in the human body. Posts.Content: Originally Posted by RobLee Ice, looks like your PSA is rising, but you probably need a few more to be sure it is up, up, up. At 4.+ it's terribly high, but when it hits ten, there's no doubt you got something going on in there. Mine kept going up, but my biopsy was negative and all my DRE's were normal. I wasn't able to get the MRI guided fusion biopsy until I changed Uro's. It was quite a struggle. As much as I hope that you do not have cancer, a negative biopsy is not proof of that... unfortunately. God bless you my man. Looking at your history in your signature is exhausting mentally but youre still kicking butt! I came to the assessment that all weve proven is that my prostate isnt eaten up with it, not that its cancer free. From the sounds of it if this test comes back positive, we go searching for the source of the cancer and eradicate it. Im pretty calm about it compared to waiting for the original biopsy. It sounds like worse case, Im in for a long exhausting journey like many here but will die of something else. Probably at the hands of my wife like shes planned for the past 26 years. It seems a shame to rob her of that ! ðŸ˜€

Posts.Content: Hi WBigs. Im curious to understand the move to treatment. The reason I ask is that were about the same age with the same PSA and the same Gleason score with almost the same involvement. Is it the perinural involvement thats driving the need? Ive seen ranges from 3 weeks to 6 weeks for being out of the office. It depends on many factors, but since it says you run marathons youre probably in good shape and will probably bounce back quicker than others. That said, my personal take is this: take all the time you can. If you feel better then use the extra time to relax and reward yourself for what youve been through and have some downtime. As for exercise Im not sure but Im sure someone will come along and provide an answer. Good luck to you!

Posts.Title: Path report is back

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by DjinTonic There is staging before RP, but I assume you doc would have to communicate this to Epstein. (Epstein is very good, but even he can't do a DRE remotely.) I'm not sure how this particular form works, but they may not bother with staging for biopsy reviews. Staging in the diagnosis phase is recorded as a "cT..." for clinical. Staging after RP begins with a "pT..." for pathologic. Clinical staging is obviously only a best estimate based on the PE and diagnostic tests/imaging. (Yes, I was confused at first, but then saw the locations of the G6 and the atypical glands.) BTW, the apex is a good location to have a single G6 core -- it's down at the tip of the prostate, away from the prostate base, which is up and closer to important anatomical structures. Since you have little to worry about, you can update your signature That is a bright spot. I was wondering if the apex wasnt bad because theres less area before any cancer made it outside the capsule. But maybe Im wrong, hopefully Im wrong. Right in the middle of the great big part away from edges and anything else important sounds pretty good.

Posts.Content: Im not sure about the results and what all of this shows...am I correct in assuming that they dont type biopsies as t1 or t2. My interpretation is that they found the G6 in the right lateral apex. The found the precancerous in the right lateral mid. Im not sure whether the adjacent high grade PIN referenced in the right lateral apex is referring to the pre-cancer noted in the right lateral mid or a completely different area. This FEELS like a yeah but result...yeah we only found a G6 but there are more problems elsewhere that we just havent narrowed down. It feels slightly worse than a simple G6. The good is that it looks like from the report that Dr. Epstein personally did the review. Anyway heres the report: Right lateral mid: Small focus of Atypical glands, highly suspicious for carcinoma Right lateral apex: Adenocarcinoma, Gleason 3+3 involving 1 core Core involvement: 20% (2mm) Adjacent High grade PIN The rest of the cores show as Benign Prostatic Tissue This is where the report gets wonky, I believe that what Im looking at is a placeholder chart thats used for both post-RP pathology and biopsies, so some information will not apply for me. So here we go: Partin Table (PSA: -, Gleason 3+3=6) Clinical stage OC EE ISV NM T1C (non palpable) - - - - T2a (Palpable <1/2 lobe) - - - - T2b,c (Palpable >1/2 lobe, bilat) - - - - (OC=Organ Conf, EE=Extrap Ext, ISV=Inv Sem Ves, NM=Nodal Mets) CAPRA/SEARCH (% patients)* Positive margins: - 3yr recurrence-free survival: - 5 yr recurrence-free survival: - *assumes clinical stage T1,2 Total cancer: <5% Total length of cancer: 2mm Total # of involved cores: 1 Total # of cores: 14 Longest tumor in single core: 2mm Max % core involvement: 20% # of cores with >50% involvement: 0 So let me have it any insights good or bad

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by DjinTonic Yes, it looks like a single form used for both biopsies and RP tissue. Looks to me that you have nothing worse than one core with G6 (3+3). Some other areas are atypical, but don't rise to a G6. I would go directly to AS, do not pass GO, do not collect more worry. What's the location of the G6 core, right lateral mid? Djin Yeah AS is the plan pending my next biopsy in 6 months. The right lateral apex is where the g6 is found. So staging of T1, T2 etc is for pathology after a prostatectomy right?
Posts.Title: Path report is back

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by DjinTonic There is staging before RP, but I assume you doc would have to communicate this to Epstein. (Epstein is very good, but even he can't do a DRE remotely.) I'm not sure how this particular form works, but they may not bother with staging for biopsy reviews. Staging in the diagnosis phase is recorded as a "cT..." for clinical. Staging after RP begins with a "pT..." for pathologic. Clinical staging is obviously only a best estimate based on the PE and diagnostic tests/imaging. (Yes, I was confused at first, but then saw the locations of the G6 and the atypical glands.) BTW, the apex is a good location to have a single G6 core -- it's down at the tip of the prostate, away from the prostate base, which is up and closer to important anatomical structures. Since you have little to worry about, you can update your signature That is a bright spot. I was wondering if the apex wasnt bad because theres less area before any cancer made it outside the capsule. But maybe Im wrong, hopefully Im wrong. Right in the middle of the great big part away from edges and anything else important sounds pretty good.

PatientDecided.Sample: And the fact that Dr Porter himself had prostate cancer and robotic surgery also played into our decision. My comments were kind of meant to be comical not critical....My husband is approaching 74 and is a survivor of a very aggressive form of leukemia, including a bone marrow transplant 5 years ago. When his PSA started fluctuating, the doctor quickly said that he would not be a candidate for surgery, primarily due to his age....With a prostate of almost 100 gms, and the BPH urination problems that went with it, I ended up having the surgery to cure both the cancer and the urination problems. That was over 7 years ago and my PSA remains zero and my urination remains at firehose levels....Thats a lot of possible future growth. If cancer ever develops I would probablygiven my prostate is already 46ml+opt to try the removal with surgery....When his PSA started fluctuating, the doctor quickly said that he would not be a candidate for surgery, primarily due to his age. I will report back as to what the urologist says....My Uro says it's still possible I'll be looking at radiotherapy after I've had a chance to heal from my RALP, due to the high risk, aggressive nature of my cancer, and my poor risk factors, but all things considered, we're cautiously positive. Sure could've been a lot worse news....The doctor was VERY gentle and nice and explained that I had 3 positive cores of Gleason 6 and that I would live out my full lifespan if I had surgery. With a prostate of almost 100 gms, and the BPH urination problems that went with it, I ended up having the surgery to cure both the cancer and the urination problems....I remember that because I was wondering if my current job would hold out that long should I need surgery. The other thing he mentioned that didnt give me great comfort is that they really didnt have AS stats regarding success past 10 years....Because of the hard sell feeling from Dr Ellis et al it reinforced my decision going with Dr Porter. And the fact that Dr Porter himself had prostate cancer and robotic surgery also played into our decision....He says "Well, it's good news: your uPSA is 0.01" Phew... So, due to a number poor-risk factors, I'm now in the "uPSA every 6 weeks, with follow-up" until 6 months post op. My Uro says it's still possible I'll be looking at radiotherapy after I've had a chance to heal from my RALP, due to the high risk, aggressive nature of my cancer, and my poor risk factors, but all things considered, we're cautiously positive....If cancer ever develops I would probablygiven my prostate is already 46ml+opt to try the removal with surgery. At least then I could guarantee no future spreading (or relatively guarantee it) and go back on hrt without worry....He didnt seem to think I could get that far down the road, he kept stating 2-3 years was his expectations. I remember that because I was wondering if my current job would hold out that long should I need surgery....
